7FU0F2OuxI_VmzVsZ_DBcQ.review_text: Great experience.  Forbes Island is something everyone should try at least once.  You must take a shuttle to the island so don't try to walk to it.  The shuttle driver was very nice and gave a quick tour upon arrival.  The island is very unique.  The men's restroom is above the water and decorated in an interesting island/tiki way.  The women's restroom is in the underwater cabin.  I most enjoyed the interior décor.  The ambience was very tranquil and classy, while keeping its out-at-sea feel.  We climbed to the top of the lighthouse after dinner and enjoyed the great view.  The service was excellent!  The menu was seasonal and fantastic.  The food was amazing.  I strongly recommend this restaurant.

YofxgpBlD4ByHYF7iOWRpA.review_text: My boyfriend took me here as a surprise for my birthday tonight (4/2) and it was probably one of the most amazing dinners I've ever had. I didn't know he was capable of making reservations, but he actually called in for a reservation weeks ago so kudos to him!   It was perfect weather walking from the garage down to Pier 39 (Forbes validates parking tickets!) and we waited just a couple of minutes for the shuttle ferry to arrive.  We were seated immediately and it didn't take long for us to realize that we were both getting a little bit nauseous from the rocking of the "island"! The dining room is cozy & it makes for a very romantic and intimate environment, but you can also definitely hear the conversations of people who are sitting two tables away.   My boyfriend ordered a glass of Cabernet and the organic salmon w/ pesto rice and I got the classic filet mignon which was actually cooked to perfection. His salmon came out great and tasted very fresh. I kinda kicked myself because I had actually wanted the lamb lollipops but was craving steak for some reason at that moment in time. Anyways, there might be more spectacular food elsewhere but being at Forbes is an entirely different dining experience from any other restaurant (one of the reasons being, you're dining "underwater").   After dinner, we walked around the grounds a bit and went up the lighthouse. Going up the stairs added to the swaying definitely brought on a minor headache but it was so worth it to see the 360-degree view at the top! I really have nothing but good things to say about dining here!

Ytq1HaAK4Dc84UnShCnI6g.review_text: What should you expect from a restaurant on a boat at Fisherman's Wharf?  We thought not much.  The interior is neat (bathrooms too), the food was amazing.  We have gone there in groups of four and in large groups and either way things were great.  I can't believe some place down in that touristy area is so great!

ave0Y9VaQi2m_VxCWGn2jg.review_text: I had this image of speeding over choppy waves...I even brought a hat, scarf, and extra jacket for the experience. Imagine my surprise when the "island" turned out to be about a one lap swim distance from the H dock of Pier 39.  How I've missed it all these years is a mystery.  No wonder i missed it, it's doesn't really look like an island from Pier 39.  While we contemplated the message from the phone saying it was "after hours," I noticed the captain himself sitting in the heated waiting area near the boat.  The "boat" was a fully covered sea taxi.  No open air ocean breeze, no need for the aforementioned winter wear.  Forbes was very hospitable and welcoming. In less time that you can say "What the hell is Forbes Island?" we were docked on the island.  After a very brief tour, we were led downstairs to the dining room. Here's where my anxiety began.  It was rocking. And not obviously so, but gently, as if we were standing on a magic carpet lost in the streets of Rome going 2 miles per hour.  But it was moving...holy crap.  I loved the ambiance, very cozy.  Forget about sitting near the portholes, there's nothing to see and you'd be sitting just next to the bar.  Quite frankly, i was scared of what would swim/float by...  For as much as I loved the experience, I wished it didn't move so much. I know many with seasoned sea legs may not be affected, but I'm very sensitive to motion.  Thankfully,  I was able to get through the entire dinner without feeling too sick.  I must say though, by the time dessert rolled around, i kept thinking "I need to get to solid ground!"  The food was good.  I wasn't expecting to be blown away, but it was not disappointing.  The warm calimari salad was quite nice, as was the sea bass special that I ordered.  We climbed the 55-stair lighthouse.  The view from the top platform was incredible.  Also, the video in the first dining room to your left was also informative and interesting.   Just remember, it's a ship, smartly disguised as an island!  No special seafaring attire needed.    OMG, just thinking about this experience makes my head swim like i'm on the Disneyland Teacups.  OOOOOhhhhhhhh.

0CEUndR7SQmTo3OF8kKg7Q.review_text: My partner and I went for dinner for his birthday, and we could not have had a better time. If you get sea sick, being downstairs might be rough as the restaurant does sway a little bit (since it's a boat). As beautiful and romantic as the downstairs dining room was, we had to move to the upstairs dining area because I do, in fact, get very bad motion sickness. The view was beautiful from the upstairs dining area! The food was to die for (I had the halibut cheeks that had the texture of scallops). Wonderful experience!

v2FoA29whuXP8WGhU3TbWw.review_text: This place is a true gem! Strangely hidden in one of the most touristy neighborhoods is this little treasure island fine dining extravaganza.  The food is delicious, the wine list expertly crafted and if you're wondering where the best place was to view the 4th July fireworks...   ...standing on top of the only privately-owned lighthouse in the US on a man-made island off Pier 41, a bottle of chilled Veuve to one side, arms wrapped around a beautiful woman and watching the synchronized fireworks display across the city on a clear night... well, this has got to be one of the all-time top spots. Total VIP, without the hassle of organizing a boat.  The staff offered impeccable, friendly, knowledgeable service and the proprietors, too, were very personable, making time to interact individually with their guests.  Erick, Darla, thanks for making our night extra special!

wwgXWXzSmcTh_mk8QHsGXg.review_text: This is such a unique place yet not many people knows about it. After living here - in the city for 10 years and have come to Fisherman Wharf a number of times ( as you know every time that you have visitors from out of town, this is the area that you need to take them to) So I probably have seen this place many many times. Yet I always thought that it 's a private property that "off limit" which now I know it's not true. Because anyone who can affords a dinner in the price tag around $50 ( or more )per person can come here( I know, it's not cheap at all)          So 2 months ago, it was the first time that i came here. My friend took me here because she knew that I work in the wedding business and she wanted my second opinion about having her wedding at this venue.         The first thing that caught my attention ( and a lot of people's attentions ), was getting on a small boat ride - to get to the Forbes Island ( this is the only way, you can get to the place ) if you get " Seasick" easily like me, It's not fun yet I still think that this is very very charming and it's a great way to arrive at the Forbes Island.          But the most surprise of all, is the view ! I know so many restaurants claim that they have the best view in town. And I would like to think I have seen a lot of great views from a lot of great restaurants and hotels But this is the one best view that I ever seen from San Francisco, Why??  Because you got to see it all ! the Golden Gate Bridge, The whole Bay, The Alcatraz, The back drop of the whole city. You see it all in very "up close and personal"  and 360 degree. The place itself decorated as an small island but NOT the up scale one and NOT the most charming one either. But I totally do not care much about the decoration anymore once I got her. Because the view itself was so marvelous.       I would rate the food ( good but not great ), the service ( friendly and could be  a bit slow ), and the decoration and over all  3 solid stars but not more but the view itself 10 stars and more.... To having a dinner or a SMALL private event here and surrounded by these views are priceless!!!!! So i told my best friend the she picked the good venue.    Then last weekend, My best friend 's wedding arrived and I have to say the whole thing ran pretty smoothly and wonderfully every guests felt in love with this place, just like i do.       So the only thing that make me knock down a star is "the boat ride" because, many times in this wedding that the guests arrived at different times but some of them got left at "The Boat Dock"!!!     As I mentioned, you need the boat ride to get to the place and they have only one boat and one captain and most of the time he ( the captain) parked his boat at the Forbes Island instead of at the Boat Dock. For that, you really needed to call Forbes Island to asked him to bring the boat to your dock and some guests complained that it  took forever (20 mins or more) for him (the captain) to bring the boat to the dock and  took them to the restaurant and this caused the guests to miss some of the important wedding programs.       All in all, this is very charming place and the best view in the whole town but the boat ride need to be handled better in the event, such as wedding, like this. Because the last thing you ever want, is your guests couldn't come to see your ceremony just because they kept waiting for the boat ride!

mm0uBivjdUWiBFimTSuZUw.review_text: I had my 50th BDAY at Forbes Island on New Years Eve. It was fantastic. A57kMV-Kkl0XZxRbQPDqWg.review_text: Forbes Island was a really great experience. If you're with someone from out of town, its a very unique dining experience.   I was really nervous at first... I'm blonde and since I'm easily confused in life I wasn't sure if I was going to have trouble finding this place. There didn't seem to be a lot of information on how the boat to the restaurant worked and I didn't want to be late for our reservation.   It was surprisingly easy! If you know where the sea lions are at, the place the boat docks at is in the same area. You just find the letter (I forget what it is now) and wait at the gate/door. Our reservation was at 5pm, and getting there at about 4:50pm was perfect.   It's a silly little boat ride, VERY short but fun! Again, this is a really neat experience for someone that's from out of town and you can definitely get the surprise factored in. The person I was with had NO idea what we were doing. It's definitely NOT an island but more like a really big floating boat/dock thing.  I read a bunch of reviews mentioning the possibility of getting sea sick.... I have to say that I consider myself pretty tough when it comes to stuff like that, but the place does sway slightly back and forth. I had to do the mind over matter... talking myself out of the sea sickness. I ended up being ok but I can see how it could be trouble for other people.   The food was great. We both had the special, some kind of fish over potatoes and it was really good! The wine that was suggested to us complimented the meal very well.   At the end we went up to the lighthouse which was a cool way to finish the night.

sWzXBAK2Ai2iwWcu50L8gg.review_text: I'll be honest that I was a little disappointed in the food. I ordered the lamb, salmon, and seafood chowder, but was not really wow-ed by any of them. They definitely weren't bad, but they didn't stand out to me either. Maybe it's because I had higher expectations considering the plates being around $30-$40/each.   However, 4 stars for the one-of-a-kind dining experience and exceptional customer service. I took my boyfriend on a surprise dinner here and he was not at all expecting to go on a boat to an underwater restaurant. It was also nice for us to take a tour of the "island" and lighthouse afterwards.   Tips for finding the boat to take you to Forbes: Walk towards the sea lions on Pier 39. Halfway there, you'll see a gate that says "I." Wait there and there's a boat that comes every 7 minutes that will come pick you up.

jwT6Fu449qgx50Y0HQuhsQ.review_text: Came here for my 30th birthday. Get reservations, we didn't and were very very lucky they had room.   The interior is subdued and very comfortable. Yes it sways back and forth, but it's a goddam boat. What do you expect? (Some other reviews are complaining about that...that's ridiculous!) Get a few drinks in you, and you won't feel a thing. A  Anyways, I literally had the best meal of my life here. Literally...not exaggerating that.   I didn't even want to go out, but came here with my wonderful gf anyways...  I knew we got it right when I tasted the clam chowder. Amazing. We shared it and passed it back and forth. Huge chunks of clam, which fall apart in your mouth..not rubbery like most clam chowders.....perfectly seasoned. And now I'm hungry again.   We got the lamb lollipops and the flat iron steak. I was going to get the filet mignon by in my small experience, filet mignon is way overrated.  Both of these, the lollipops and steak, were the best I've ever had. I've paid a stupid amount of money for steaks before and most of them have been "meh"....Most restaurants just sous vide the meat and think it's good to go.   The steak was probably sous vide'd (not complaining, it's the best way to cook thick cuts, but I think people misuse the technique).... but they added a delicious curst to the steak..and the sauce on it was amazing. I don't like steak with sauces drizzled on, but the sauce was as good as the steak.   As for the lamb lollipops...best again. I recommend putting a little salt scattered on a plate next to the entree and "dipping" in the lollipops as needed. Careful of course b/c over-salting will kill it.   Finished it off with the creme brulee. It was delicious, but I can't provide much input as it's the first one I ever had..and was of course great.   The staff was great. Very friendly, not intimidating (as some staff can be with 30+ dollar menus).   Down to earth.   Also teh views were amazing. They encourage you to walk around, get some air...go up top the light house..hang out.   Very relaxing.   Great great time.

Y8j9qHpOz8b26f5gu3Z9Xg.review_text: this place seems to get either 3 star reviews, or 5 star reviews.  i'm in the 5 star camp.  allow me to explain the factors involved in this.  - the restaurant is in (as in, literally in) fisherman's wharf, the tourist armpit of san francisco. - you get on a pontoon boat to travel, at most, 50 meters to an "island" that is a floating house, which is driven by the owner of the restaurant. - upon arrival, the owner takes you on a tour of the "island", complete with palm trees, a 40 foot lighthouse, fountains, a beach, etc. - you eat underwater, a place which, the owner is quick to show from old photos, appears to have been the slickest bachelor pad in existence in the 70's, when the restaurant was previously his house. - if it has been a windy / choppy day, do not come here under any circumstances.  again, it's a houseboat.  it will move with waves.  and you're below deck eating and drinking. - the wine list is terribly skewed toward expensive, over-exposed selections.  we selected a $55 bottle and it was one of the cheapest things you'd actually want to drink on the menu. - the food was average.  not great, not bad, average.  it didn't upset me. - the server was pretty attentive, and very nice, but belonged in an applebees. - our bill was $200 for two people, with no dessert.  when your wine is only $55, let's all agree that this is fucking steep at any restaurant period.  you can do a full course dinner at gary danko / masa's / michael mina for this cost. - after dinner, we climbed the lighthouse and surveyed the fine view that is fisherman's wharf - the owner returned with his pontoon boat after, at most 90 seconds.  he was extremely interested in how good our dinner was.  we lied and told him it was amazing.  he was really happy about it.  conclusion:  at gary danko, the owner of the restaurant doesn't take you in a pontoon boat to a houseboat with palm trees, show you old pictures of his converted swag pad where he banged a ton of girls when he was in his 30's, encourage you to climb a lighthouse on said houseboat after dinner, and then take you back to land in a boat while genuinely caring what you thought of the experience.  you pay for what you get.  you don't go to disney world and then complain that your $12 hot dog isn't the best you've ever tasted.  the end

goH2ZGR80MaJnIzrKH2C8w.review_text: Brought my girlfriend here for our Anniversary.  1) The restaurant has an awesome atmosphere. You have to go underground on the island where you eat below the water line. Lighting and design is incredibly and AMAZINGLY cozy with a fireplace in the middle. Decorated like a ship with dark browns and reds with lots of Sea type painting.  2) The waiters are AMAZING. Super friendly and on the ball. All of them are amazingly kind and incredibly professional. Some of the best I have come across.  3) The reason for the stars would be due to Food and ironically, the location. I ordered the Risotto and my girlfriend had the chicken. I feel like for the quality of food it was overpriced a bit and tasted just OK. Looked nice on the dish though. A bit bland and limited menu as well.  Also, the biggest problem we ran into is that when you are under the island in the restaurant you can feel it swaying back and forth just slightly. It did mess with my head a little and I could deal with it but it VERY MUCH made my girlfriend sick. We ended up having to leave before she touched her food. If you can't deal with swaying or being on a boat I wouldn't recommend eating at Forbes.  4) I didn't drink at the bar but they have one upstairs and downstairs. There was a small group of people at the upstairs bar and it looked like it could be fun to go to with some friends. You don't really experience the swaying feeling upstairs.  5) All in all... I loved the atmosphere a lot and I would definitely return for special occasions. I would also like to try more of the menu since I've only experienced two dishes.

jiPzk6m4yf451hkhUYQI_A.review_text: We went to Forbes Island for my boyfriend's belated birthday celebration, and it was truly a special experience. It's a bit expensive for my taste, so thank goodness his company was paying for it as a birthday present, but I'd say that it's almost worth the price for the delicious food and the experience (and you should know at this point that I'm quite cheap.)  I had the avocado, crab, and scallop salad followed by the Canadian salmon with spinach and pesto rice. The rice was melt in your mouth amazing, and the whole entree was one of the most delicious things I've ever eaten. The salmon was a tiny bit overcooked though. The appetizer was good, but not spectacular. My boyfriend started with a green salad that looked like nothing special to me, but for his entree, he had the flatiron steak and potatoes and really enjoyed them - the steak was cooked perfectly, and I loved the seasoning on the potatoes.   We dressed up semi-formal for it and didn't feel out of place, but we could have gotten away with jeans too.  It was fun walking around the "island" (it's actually a converted houseboat, we were told) afterward while we sobered up for the trip home. There's a beautiful view from the lighthouse, and the whole experience is a fun and entertaining one.  The staff was super nice and friendly, and I highly recommend the place for a special occasion dinner.

UhhgTJxhCvowS490hfx7mw.review_text: My husband and I are from So Cal but come up to SF as much as possible. We do not hang around the tourist infested piers or do anything remotely close to what a tourist would do while here. Our close friend saw Forbes Island Restaurant on a food show and we have suggested dinner here. We have never heard or saw this restaurant in the area but agreed to dinner.   We arrived on Sunday and decided to walk to the end of the pier to get a view of this floating island/restaurant. We were surprised to see it floating like a boat at the end of the pier. We wondered how the seating fit into this floating island and decided, this will be a fun experience. The following day we arrived for dinner.  The short boat ride was cute and fun. The Captain, Ryan was happy to welcome us on his "boat" and gave us a short history lesson on Forbes Island.   The experience was fun, different and the food was delicious. It was interesting to see the restaurant below, the bar upstairs and the very cool looking lighthouse. Yes, the decor is not modern, however it not old and it fits in perfectly with our dinner. We often go to restaurants like The Brown Derby, The Magic Lamp and The Sycamore Inn which have the same decor however no one EVER says anything negative about the "outdated" furniture. It adds to the great experience.   Our server, Dakota was just as great as the food and experience. I had the halibut cheeks dinner with risotto and a side of great tasting leeks. my husband had the braised short ribs with very creamy mashed potatoes and yams. There is nothing bad that I can say about our meal. I was very impressed and decided at that moment that I was going to return the next time I was in town.   I have had spent 3 times more on dinners that were equally as delicious as our meal, service and drinks at Forbes Island.  I strongly encourage everyone to come in and give this place a try. It is definitely different and worth the experience. Don't let the 2 or 3 stars prevent you from coming in.   Obviously some reviewers loved the food but didn't like the rocking of the restaurant. Um, hello....your floating on the water and currents will make the restaurant move. Duh.   If you are a foodie, review on the food and grade on the food..not the decor. After all, how many people give 5 stars for a food truck parked on a busy street.....ALOT. If the food is good, it's worth the stars. If you just didn't like the server, say it in the review or contact the owner. That's it.  I loved it and will return.

S0SHI0l0G5yV9iFwPleNlQ.review_text: Food is wonderful! The views are gorgeous. I honestly don't know how people can fault the restaurant for the boat moving.. you are eating on a boat. Make reservations, ladies make sure to visit the womens bathroom, and definitely climb the lighthouse!  Dakota was a great server make sure you request him if you can!

G5LXEaxhQMF_BVjNHkVr7g.review_text: This is a real San Francisco treat, you have to go take a small boat that picks you up at Pier 39 for a quick cruise over to the island itself; the last time we went, Forbes Island Creator Mr. Forbes Kiddoo himself was captaining the vessel! Upon arrival on the island, we went up to the lighthouse for a unique view of the sea lions, then down to the new Tahiti Lounge for a quick cocktail. For dinner, below deck, we settled into our table and got used to the gentle sway of the ocean. Dinner was better than average - the rack of lamb is a standout - but you're really here for the atmosphere. I saw some business colleagues enjoying a drink at the bar, now that's an interesting idea for an after-work libation...

uDpbI6fH93ETr5NzwFP5EQ.review_text: We were there for our niece's 50th birthday so it was a special night for us.  Our party got separated so we had to wait for our other table guests to arrive.  We asked the waitress for some bread and she refused.  She said bread is only served with the entrees.  When the bread did come, she brought 3 pieces of bread for a table of eight.  The service was slow.  When we had been to Forbes, the previous year for my birthday, I was given a free dessert with a candle in it.  When I asked the waitress if this could be done for my niece and the waitress continued to argue with me that I wasn't given any free dessert last year.  We all bought desserts and then the waitress came back to again tell me how wrong I was about getting a free dessert last year.  She was inappropriate and rude.  We spent over $500 that night and I would have liked to have had pleasant time and not this problem.  I'm sure most restaurants would have supplied a free birthday dessert when a patron has spent over five hundred dollars.  Give me a freakin break.    We waited for 15 minutes for the ferry to take us back to the "mainland" and we finally asked the captain if he could start the boat so we could leave.  He said he wanted to wait for more people.  It was cold and my niece was due for her insulin injection, which was in our car.  We told him that she was diabetic and he was drilling us about what kind of diabetes did she have and he knows about it because he is a class 2 type of diabetic.  What difference does that make?  We need to get back to the car.  He finally started the boat and we were on our way.  I will NEVER go there again.

K5as-hBg2K4oAP-J54iX3w.review_text: Came for Dine About Town and had a great time.  The food was good, the service great, and the ambiance out of this world. It was kitsch, but kitsch done very well. SiWKkld0A-CzbRc6BXOTNA.review_text: It is not exactly the place I would plan to go have dinner. However, I was invited by friends once, in 2004. It was a very nice experience. WJYSt5sYapBxBP0RBqsX2g.review_text: DO IT. No seriously, you need to go to this place to experience it at least once! How cool! A floating island! Pog1qbdOS8HK4AmgrGgtHQ.review_text: Great date night! 1iYdD-BcWhqtJYHcHkFPXA.review_text: This place was freaking awesome! Food great! Service great! Everything great! Nothing like eating under the sea! Kept looking for James Bond!

vSqlFhnB3GGZsjX4OPm9CQ.review_text: This is a great place to take someone on a date - a little corny, but still cute! From the pier, you are picked up by a little ferry that takes you to the boat, which is set up like an island.  This little boat is filled with palm trees, sand, even a little pirate dummy. The seating area was a little tight, but if you're on a date you can call it cozy. The food here was definitely on point. pJQNx6BsCyYGNNYlFdnfAQ.review_text: We went for my husband's birthday in January 2014.  The whole feeling starts when you take the boat to the island.   The Captain gives a briefing of the island and you can look around.  The ambiance, you actually feel like you are dining on a moving ship.  It very gently swayed.  I was a little nervous because I get motion sick on a muni bus but I had no effect here, thank God!   It was so chilly so we figured we'd hit the lighthouse after dinner.  We were seated and ordered our drinks.  Our very friendly waiter suggested going up after we get our drinks, it was beautiful. When we were done touring the lighthouse we ordered our food.   We had Caesar Salad and the Avocado Bruschetta which we both enjoyed.  For dinner, I had the Flat Iron, done perfectly, and my husband had the fish special which he really enjoyed.  We were so full for dessert but the waiter brought out a strawberry with cream and a thin lattice cookie with Happy Birthday written out in Chocolate.  He made it very special!    They had postcards they get mailed from Forbes Island.  We were excited & wrote out a few.  NONE of they were mailed.  We offered to pay for them!  We like to mail postcard to ourselves of places we've been & so we know that they weren't mailed.  That was our only drawback.  I save stuff like that & if I would've known they wouldn't be mailed, I would've taken it with me to mail later!  Bummer.  Overall, I can't wait to take our grown kids here!  Definitely is a night to remember!

eKPyzjeGW06tpiTcln0sNA.review_text: Ate there to celebrate our 20th anniversary on 11-20-10. it was a stormy night: thunder and lightening. We had made reservations weeks ahead to be there in time for the sunset, but given the rainy weather that was really a moot point.  We had the champagne (not great) and the chicken dish. Well, It was blander than bland. Imagine a boiled leg  of chicken with a slice of deli cheese somewhat melted over and drowning in a tasteless pool of white cream!  That was surrounded by bland mashed potatoes and green beans lost in the bottom of the plate. Who cooks like this?? I can make better food at home while drunk out of my mind!!!! Yuck! We both had a glass of wine too and the bill, get this, came to over $100, with tip over $120. It was not worth half of this! On top of that, the parking was supposed to be validated, however we had to fork $8 for it. Deceiving!  I have to say the service was good and the decor is cool too. It would also be nice if whatever we are chewing on had some taste.  Don't plan to go back. EVER!!!

WCKi9Y-h0q2royecqByx3w.review_text: This is more of fun night out or a touristy thing to do, it's not actually an island it's a floating man made lighthouse/dock/thingamajig, but still fun none the less. You have to go out to Fisherman's warf right where pier 39 begins and there is a blue awning and you board the boat from a tiny dock. The boat ride is fun although really short, honestly it looks like you can jump from one of the docks near pier 39 and land on the island. So the skipper takes you to the makeshift "island" and you deboard (I don't know you deboard a boat or is it called something else?) and Gilligan greets you and takes you the restaurant. You go downstairs and actually the dining is underwater. Ginger will welcome you to the restaurant and show you to your table. Mary Ann takes your order and brings you some really good food. The dungeness crab and scallop salad is very good, but I always feel funny eating fresh crab meat that is already out of the shell. Always feels like there's a guy back there sucking the meat out of the shell and plating it, I dunno' maybe it's just me.  anyways the Avocado Bruschetta is good and so are the baby greens. Then Professor will cook you some very tender short ribs for your entree although a little too sweet for my taste, and the Iron steak, filet mignon are delish (of course). The risotto is very creamy and tasty. Thurston Howell the third, will bring you plenty of bread and the potatoes au gratin sides are good, although to cheesy for my stomach to be easy (gosh darn lactose intolerance!!!). The atmosphere is like 1940s ocean-liner-esque, pictures of old salty dawgs, nautical knick-knacks and there are actual port holes (windows) that are open to the water, but there is so much algae growing on them you cannot see anything but the color green. I didn't see Mrs. Howell but I guess she's in the back washing the dishes. afterwards you can walk about the small "island" go to the top of the light house to take pictures etc. etc. then the boat takes you on a less than 3 hour tour (about 5 minutes) back to the dock. It's innocent fun and if you get stuck on the island just use some coconuts and string and call the mainland, somebody will come rescue you, have fun.

0RHUgJ-dwwu7fR_FtzOh2w.review_text: My fiance and I had come here for two of our anniversaries over the years. It has always been such a magical place, full of romance!  Forbes Kiddoo (the owner of the island) is the usual boat taxi-er from dock to island and he always makes wonderful conversation and just makes you feel so welcome and special getting to visit his private island. But this evening Chris taxi'd us to and fro and he was equally fun to ride in a boat with and shared stories of people getting married and engaged on the island.  My favorite dish is the steak with green beans and potatoes au-gratin, there is this delicious mustard sauce on top of the steak and it is to die for. I think about it all the time.  Since we love this place so much we really want to consider it as a wedding venue, however, with limited capacity (max. in restaurant is 65) I don't think my dream wedding on Forbes Island will come true, but we are happily considering having our rehearsal dinner here!  You can rent the rooms on the top of the island, one with a bar and a fire place and a lovely view of the city, and the other room seats a few more people and has a lovely view of the bay, the Golden Gate Bridge... it's gorgeous on both sides of the island, truly. You can even reserve the whole restaurant or even the whole island! We are tempted! The main guy in charge is Casey and he is really friendly and very informative and flexible. The bartender, Pierre, is very easy to talk to and informative as well. We had a lovely time this evening enjoying the house wines at the bar, the fireplace and the swaying chandelier as we went over all of the different options for having a wedding here.

NKJx5ye6fafAG-8RSjwfZQ.review_text: Kind of cheesy but I got to experience it :-D  I was here on a Friday evening for a rehearsal dinner.  The whole island was rented for the night so it was purely our party.  The weather was a bit gusty so the island was swaying and chilly.  I'm sensitive out at sea and despite it's close proximity to Pier 39, I was turning a little green.    While on the island, visit the lighthouse, before drinking!  With a rocking island for a base,it was challenging to get up those steps but the views at the top was worth it.  That day we were all taken off guard and didn't quite have our sea legs or shoes to match, most of us girls were in stilettos  and platforms so walking about was challenging, my heel went through a few planks on deck.  The little hut served as a wine bar while the full bar downstairs catered everyone else.  Dinner was served downstairs and minus the rocking was good.  Luckily the host provided pressure bands for those like myself and I was able to eventually enjoy dinner and the company.  The bartender downstairs was very accommodating with all the relatives clamoring for drinks at an open bar, you can just imagine.  The decor was pirate so the captains room doubled as the ladies lounge and powder room, very cozy.    I'm glad to have enjoyed this SF treat minus the tab and next time, wedge shoes...

L5fRLjek7brqA2iqlL3-ZQ.review_text: Fun and fabulous! What a wonderful treat! The food is excellent. The service is excellent. The drinks are excellent. And the ability to go up the lighthouse and spend time just kickin' on the island is the icing on the cake. This is a true delight!

QFET9AomXpKsAg1kh9BJHg.review_text: Five stars for the whole experience! Came here to celebrate valentines day, 2 days after with kids in tow. Its happening more and more these days. I made a reservation for 5:45, got lost, finally found our way to pier 39 after an hour or so. We told him we did but were sooo late for it. He took us anyway hoping they will still let us dine. To my surprise they did! Were talking about one hour late here, haha.. They take u down under water which isnt a good idea when youre prone to vertigo or dizziness coz the place is enclosed and u feel the movement but u dont see it. I wanted to have a cocktail but i knew itll only make me queasy. Food isnt the best but still good. We had the caesar salad for appetizer, i had the organic salmon, the hubby had the chicken. And u know how their menu isnt kid-friendly? The waiter offered to make my 2 kids pasta with butter sauce that was on the house! I appreciate it so much. I know its just spaghetti with garlic butter but my kids devoured it like theres no tomorrow, haha! That was pretty nice of them. Later on after were done eating we climbed up to the lighthouse. Pls take a camera, for the view is spectacular up there! We walked around the "island", took all the pix we need. They even have a heater out on the deck, it was just beautiful in every way. Only downside is the rocking! But i got over it after a while. We own a boat but somehow i still get dizzy!

c6OBvQwgfFU7-x9jS9rE1w.review_text: Everyone should try it at least once. Really good food, unique setting and nice wine list. Make reservations. Be aware that you will feel a little motion from being on the water - some people who are really susceptible to motion sickness might have a hard time.

ZYlGy3MajSpCGPurmjqBNg.review_text: One of my all time best date night memories with my boyfriend.  So it's right next to pier 39, you go to this dock and use their phone to call the restaurant to let them know you need to be picked up.  They come over in their water taxi and you go on a cute little 5minute boat ride to the island.  Once you get onto the island, they will let you walk around and explore the area if you like.  After dinner we walked up the stairs to the light tower and the view of the bay was beautiful at night.  As for the dinner, They first bring out this amazing warm, soft bread and they have this sea salt butter which was to die for. I can still taste it!! I would go back just for the bread and butter alone, no joke.  Our main entree I had the Sea Bass which was amazing!  Cooked really well and super moist!  But i'm sure everything is just as good there!  PS, it was so awesome, i went back for my uncles birthday a couple months later.  Everyone loved not only the experience, but the food also.  I didn't really feel the rocking? One time we sat under water, and the 2nd time we got the chance to sit upstairs, literally on top of the water, all views of the SF bay.  It was gorgeous.  I highly recommend this place for either a date, or a banquet type event.

kRAAY2EKtUMfPNW7tFqnTA.review_text: We had dinner here last night.  It was a great experience!  The dining room, below deck, was magnificent!  We started with a French 75 and a Mai tai, then the Filet Mignon and Petrale Sole.  Ended with Irish coffee, creme brulee and chocolate moose.  Our waiter was also great.  We are glad we went.

ZCuCg7yNcbB6-KbCuT3f6A.review_text: My wife and I came here for our anniversary - it was our first time.  We were so impressed that we came back a month later for her 40th birthday, along with 20 friends.  The restaurant has two rooms you can reserve, one with a capacity of 18 and the other 28.  Casey, who helps coordinate special events, took great care of us, and was very responsive during the weeks leading up to the event.  I wanted everything to be perfect for my wife's party, and Casey had a very professional, caring attitude, telling me, "I don't want you to have to worry about a thing."  We provided him with menu choices (3 entrees + 1 veggie) and a dessert option.  He also provided a stereo where I plugged my iPod in.  Our guests raved about the unique environment - it's like eating on a boat.  They climbed up the lighthouse and checked out the views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz.  Service was impeccable, in that California casual/formal way.  Forbes, the restaurant owner, picked everyone up in his boat with a big smile, and I think our friends were charmed to pieces.  An unforgettable night, thanks to the staff at Forbes Island.

w_TLPX80L-puqNjOBEPTeQ.review_text: I'm going to have to side with the other reviewers that thought this place was great. We had two appetizers (the avocado bruschetta and the mushrooms) two entrees (I had the salmon and my husband had the sole), and two desserts (apple tart and chocolate mousse). All were delicious.  The atmosphere - kind of kitschy, but you have to admit that it is definitely unique. It is impressive that the wooden molding inside of the building is secured without a single nail. The staff were also great - everyone was so friendly and attentive. As others have said, the restaurant does sway (it's afloat and you see fish swimming past the portholes), so if you're prone to seasickness or claustrophobia (you're seated below deck) then it probably isn't the place for you. Anyway, we enjoyed our visit and plan to return.

yZyUc9ChBerAAeUY8ygSfw.review_text: I didn't get sick!   Here's a review of an _event_ on the island, which is different from a regular review because--  1. Weeee!! Did my inebriation affect my opinion? and how drunk was I? Well I didn't dry-hump the pirate lady statue. But I did scream "fish! fish! fish!" when this dinky little fish swam by the porthole.   About the portholes.
