LQ3wuja7RygHk8eoDlfrSQ.review_text: What can I say?  I LOVE Forbes Island.  Hell, the ferry over there with Mr. Forbes is worth it alone.  Be sure that you give yourself plenty of time to wander the island.  Climb the light house tower.  Check out the ladies room (inside the Captain's Quarters).  Chat with the staff.  Make friends with other diners.  Watch fishies swim past the portholes.  It's expensive but this is an all night experience and it's just delightful.  So romantic!  So fun!  So different!  Reservations are required and you must be on time as you take a boat to get there.

2GFd25Kgkj1OhGXqpup3Xw.review_text: I ate at Forbes Island last night, taking advantage of dine about town and had a wonderful time, despite the fact that they are not exactly the most veggie friendly joint!  Started with the butternut squash soup which happens to be one of my favorite soups despite the fact that this one was a bit over salted!  The entree portion was a little difficult since I am a vegetarian (and had told them when making my reservation!).  Our waitress kept trying to persuade me to order off the regular menu even though I was insisting I had come and made reservations for the dine about town menu.  After a bit of backing and forthing, which I will chalk up to a language barrier, she offered to make me a veggie platter: cooked carrots, peas, green beans and then a slice of both the potato gratin and broccoli/mushroom fluffy pastry.  The latter two were amazing, and while I enjoyed the veggies, especially since they were not overcooked and still had a delightful snap and crunch to them.  While enjoyable, I hardly think a couple cooked veggies and potato gratin comes close to the worth of any of the meat options available, but I suppose that's what I get for being a vegetarian?  The meal ended with a bang, however, since the chocolate mousse was very chocolatey but thankfully not overly sweet and hit the spot!  I will say that despite the little fuss in the beginning regarding a veg meal, our server was very friendly, attentive, and amicable!  I think most of the appeal was the location- AN ISLAND- and the experience of exploring it before/after dinner.  I highly recommend climbing to the top of the lighthouse to see a fantastic view and exploring the different dinning areas with other fantastic views of Alcatraz and the Pier 39 Sea Lions!  I will also note for those who do not know/did not read the instructions on their website, that you cannot actually WALK to Forbes.  There is a Forbes ferry taxi near the docks at pier 39 (or somewhat close by) that will take you there and back.  Also, for those of you who are easily motion/seasick prone, you can feel the waves beneath you as you dine.  Although the food is about average at best (in terms of vegetarian options at least) Forbes Island is a MUST for tourists and San Franciscans alike- if only once for the experience!

j4zryue2DzH1TKJSAjqi3g.review_text: Everything about this cheesy, crazy restaurant is amazing!  Now, mind you, you're not going for food.  And this review is informed by the wedding rehearsal dinner of a very dear friend of mine.  But...IT'S AMAZING!  Let's count the ways.  First, it's a boat...ISLAND?!...in San Francisco Bay.  Which you take a boat, ferry, if you will, to get to.  And then you go way down into said boat?  Island?  And it's like this cavern.  With all these amazing nooks and places to steal a kiss.  How awesome is that?  But it gets...EVEN better!  There's a miniature lighthouse on this boat/island!  Which you can easily go up into.  Again...romantic as hell!  And you're across the bay from Alcatraz.  Who isn't slightly mesmerized by that?  (Go if you never have.  Seriously.)    The food isn't going to be what you remember most.  But it's not half bad.  What you are going to remember is the experience.  And, even 3 years later, I remember it so fondly I can't stand it.  It's a truly awesome experience.  Lose yourself in it.  And hopefully do so with the ones you love!  Forbes Island rocks!

hEjhuWxQwDvP_B8yeCjDYg.review_text: PreAmble:  Without any compelling reason to visit, I usually stay clear of Fisherman's Wharf. Curiosity & a special occasion gave rise to my inner tourist, which is in hibernation unless I am in a place that is more than a 4 hour plane ride away.  Its hard to think that Forbes Island goes unnoticed given the white lighthouse, a cluster of mature palm trees floating near Pier 39, and a boat moored next to it festooned with "ForbesIsland.com". Seeing it many years ago, I thought it might be the SF pied-et-terre of Malcom Forbes, who ascended to the Billionaire beach in the ether a while back... the same guy who's magazine still bears his name all these years later.  At that time, my curiosity didn't take me any closer in understanding what this odd site was.  Curiosity in the present, and a dinner reservation brought visions of being among the folks that love eating clam chowder out of a hollowed out round "sour dough" loaf, with some gleefully barking how beautiful the SF bay is.   Getting to the island:  There is a dock next to Pier 39, with a description of Forbes Island on a stand. Standing outside the locked wire gate, there are no hints as to how often the boat arrives or how to signal the boat to come. Serenaded by sea lions perched on their barges near by.  The boat arrives and we were then serenaded with a history lesson of the restaurant by the chatty 'captain' of the boat, a fun short boat ride to the island.   Dinner & Service  3 of us for dinner. Filet Mignon, Sole, & Iron Steak were the entree's. Each accompanied by a veggie, some sort of potatoes (scalloped ?). Nicely prepared and tasty. Service was exceptional. The environment is like being below deck on a (older) yacht, with plenty of wood and nautical themed decorations. The crowd was fairly diverse, with a leaning to that "mature" segment. Not a boisterous tourist crowd, it was ... pleasant.

nPlV4Bq7qwkq-tTXT3daSA.review_text: It's been over a year since I came here, but I feel that I would be doing all my readers a injustice by not writing a review about this place. Guys: this is one of those places you just HAVE to take your lady to. Unless of course she gets seasick easily.  Park at Pier 39 parking lot and walk across the street to the docks.Pick up the phone and a gentleman will be on the other end asking you if you need to be picked up . He will then come on a little boat and pick you and your date up and shuttle you over to the island/restaurant. It's only a 3 minute boat ride, but this part of it just adds to the whole experience.   Upon approaching the island, you notice the lighthouse and the small little bungalos  in which you can dine . When we got there, we were escorted downstairs in to a dining area that felt like a capatins den.    The food was pretty good, not mind blowing, but good. The service was excellent , and the ambiance was exactly what a romantic night called for.   After we ate, we decided to walk around the little island . I thought it was pretty cool that we were allowed to walk tothe top of the lighthouse. The view was pretty awesome.  This is a must dine restaurant if you are looking to take your loved one out to a a unique , romantic experience. They only accept reservations. Check it out and let me know what you think .

MzGBbp_k7G6bOJRoKJDTKA.review_text: TOO CUTE!  The dock to get on the boat is right next to Pier 39, on the outside. There's a little sign and a ramp. The Captain was nice, but got upset when some people had the wrong number of guests in their party. It was a little weird. The lighthouse is very cute; it's worth the walk up to the top. The restaurant itself is very small, intimate. Unless you're right by a porthole you don't notice you're underwater. The resturant does sway a bit, but we didn't get sick or anything.  The caesar salad is good, a little mild. The avocado bruschetta is weird, but ok. The potatoes au gratin is very good. I would also recommend the chocolate martini.

67tUYddjTd7V-bcG0t6CHg.review_text: It's a FREAKIN island!!!  That moves.  And you DINE in it!  A little boat picks you up and shuttles you to the island; if you're lucky, you'll get the owner/host himself in his navy blue blazer.    Cozy romantic ambience.    You enjoy panoramic views above deck on the "island" and underwater views into the bay below deck in the dining room through the portholes.    There's a lighthouse you can climb and what looks like a well-appointed bedroom suite for when they start playing "Let's get it on".  Did I mention...it's a FREAKIN island?!!!  Try it at least once...definitely an only-in-San Francisco experience.

djxnI8Ux8ZYQJhiOQkrRhA.review_text: Forbes Island Fridays! Ruggy J discovered this little island bar/restaurant right off of Pier 39 not too long ago and decided to turn Friday happy hour into Forbes Island Fridays.   Here's the lowdown: - Get down to Fisherman's Wharf. Look in-between Pier 39 and 41 - there should be a small floating island with a lighthouse attached to it. That's where you're headed. - There's a boat shuttle that takes you from the Pier to the island. It runs every 5-10 minutes or so. Wait there for them to take you across. Forbes (*the guy*) is the captain. - Head downstairs (below water line) to the bar. Sit down and chat it up with Pierre, the man behind the bar. He can mix just about any drink that you'd like, including some island themed cocktails and sparking wine. - Order some nosh if you're hungry. I'd recommend the bruschetta, complete with avocado, tomato and balsamic. - Don't worry if you feel a little rocking - it's normal. - Check out the ladies restroom. It used to be Forbe's bedroom. Very classy!  After an hour or two of rocking back and forth, I was starting to get a little woozy. But if you've got stronger sea legs, stick around for dinner. The island can accommodate up to 100+ guests at a time, so call ahead for a reservation and make it an unforgettable dining experience!

7MlkesSFpa-kyrrn55Pm5A.review_text: We'd been wanting to go to Forbes Island for a long time and finally went late on a Saturday evening on a whim while in the city. The owner/builder of the artificial island met us at the dock to ferry us over and was very friendly. We called ahead for reservations and were seated promptly down in the dining room below the waterline. Our table didn't have a porthole but there was one right behind me. There was nothing to see though except green, murky water. Our server was knowledgeable and helpful. While the food was very good, there was a slight problem with one dish which we hesitantly mentioned and our server gave us a free dessert as an apology even though we neither asked for nor expected anything!   The island has 2 above-water rooms for private parties as well as a lighthouse and other areas to explore and walk around, but most diners will be downstairs in the main dining room. Between the slightly cramped but not uncomfortable seating arrangements, the slightly too warm and stuffy air and the fact that you're underwater, I could see how someone prone to claustrophobia might not like it. We were fine though. Also, occasionally the island would move slightly, probably when the launch pulled up alongside so, if you get motion sickness, perhaps a Dramamine or Bonine before dinner?  Of note, a lot of our fellow patrons were drinking quite a bit. This wasn't a problem in the dining room, but as we made our way outside there were a number of individuals being rather loud and obnoxious. iQaU95JQMs3yg4qB8bhFTg.review_text: Forbes Island Restaurant - A Floating Disappointment   As you gaze out from Pier 39 you might feel the chill of excitement at the look of the delightful looking Forbes Island Restaurant, for how often is it that you see a Light House perched on a tiny island with views which overlook the bay?  Today was the first and the last time I will step foot on that floating disguised boat, and I will not be sad about that. Instead I am more concerned at the high ratings such an unimpressive offer receives.  Magical as though it may look. Do not be mistaken. Unfortunately this is little more then a gimmicky American restaurant of which it's continued success rests on it's Disney like appearance and novelty value.  I was kindly taken out to dinner this evening to Forbes and as quaint as the little Island looked from the minute I walked down the plank to the pontoon and I met our pilot on a rather rusty looking vessel with dubious looking safety vests i began to have suspicions that this was not going to be a fairytale.   Based on online ratings, most people seems happy to ignore the fishy smell that greets you as you descend the stairs to what is described as underwater dining experience and is little more then a decorative boat hull with no windows only grimy portholes with coverings. The lack of light and motion of the boat may make some unwell, or perhaps that is to encourage drinking so as to ignore the awful decor. The other diners do not inspire confidence in shambolic attire. Surely a place which makes the New York times should inspire an audience of people who appreciate food? Luckily with an uninspiring yet reasonably well executed menu there isn't much to get excited about or not, unless of course your waiter some how hears fillet instead of salmon and then when the mistake is made takes some time before offering any discount or satisfactory remedy to the fact half the parties food is getting cold while a salmon is being found and thrown together.  I'm not fond of being preached to about the reviews of other critics either. Just because one person is prepared to be rocked into boredom does not mean I am for the price of a meal you could have had with a view and less of a smell.  My steak was fine but the smell of fish was so haunting I was distracted. The meal was at the price you would expect for novelty but not for quality. I would not recommend this to anyone unless they have only a serious interest in the structure of the boat as that is actually interesting - however can be discovered at a far cheaper price by reading the website.  Forbes Island: 39 Pier #205San Francisco, CA 94133 (415) 951-4900

PsF-A4zQ2n7o1SF6oUNjcw.review_text: 5 stars are for the service, friendliness of everyone working there, the ambiance, and how romantic this place was.... unfortunately I couldn't comment on the food because well, I got the worst case of motion sickness even before our appetizer arrived!!    WARNING: DO NOT come here if you have even the slightest case of motion sickness!    I wanted to take my hubby somewhere different for his 30th birthday to make it more memorable... we were both excited, it was a cute idea... take a little mini boat ride to a little island and dine on a floating island under water... the boat ride was fine, I don't really get sea sick... I've dined on cruises and been on boats multiple times... the only time I've ever felt sea sick was whale watching in Monterey.  As soon as we were seated, I could feel a swaying motion.  It was a really windy night too.  We ordered drinks and our meals.  Our drinks came... rnmS7HPVh77oE5NlPVy0RQ.review_text: I was looking for the perfect place to take my girlfriend for our anniversary and I stumbled upon Forbes Island. I thought that this was the perfect place! It had a really romantic feel to the place, I felt like it was the perfect choice, until the food came. I ordered the Filet Mignon and my girlfriend ordered the seasonal half rack of lamb. WLRWL4WGhjK23lZWXKaTmw.review_text: It's a restaurant on an island/ship floating 20 feet from the pier in San Francisco. Did you really think it wasn't going to be touristy? nDvYMphelPzk8I_mWaPRPg.review_text: My first time here was about two years ago, some time in December. I went here for my five year anniversary with the boyfriend, and I must say this was probably one of my proudest find, ever.   I wanted to do something different that year, so I decided to find a fine-dine spot with a gorgeous view. If you haven't been here, please do. I recommend it for first dates, celebration of an anniversary, or just a nice night out. It is the cutest place in the city, located on a man made island, right across from pier 39. You can actually see the island filled with bright lights from Fisherman's Wharf after sunset.    You'd need to make reservation online, and I would recommend to do this a couple of weeks before your date. They're usually pretty booked. Once you get to Fisherman's Wharf, you would be transported to Forbes Island through one of their transit boats, and if dinner is at night, it'll be a breath taking view you won't forget.   The main restaurant is located underneath the boathouse, with a full bar (if I remember right) and since the restaurant is located underwater, do beware of motion sickness. When we arrived, we were quite pleased to be seated right next to a warm fireplace, since it's been raining out. We ordered Pan Seared Flat Iron Steak and the French Country Style Chicken, both were delish! For dessert, we had the Berry Napoleon with Mascarpone Crème & Hazelnut Tuiles with an after dinner cocktail.   Their wine list was good. Plenty of selections on wine and cocktails to choose from. Now, the best part of the night is the gorgeous view of San Francisco on top of the lighthouse, outside the restaurant. It is definitely a romantic spot to cuddle with your lover on a cozy night in SF.   I highly recommend! I can't wait to come back here again!

K2iVwsx-Jnnf-fsSY4Iwgg.review_text: Overall, I was disappointed by our dinner at Forbes Island.  We won't be going back, and I'd not recommend it to others.  FOOD The food is quite expensive (we paid $100 for two people) and supposed to be great, but my mushroom risotto was kind of weird (sweet and herby), and my husband's filet mignon was tender, but nothing special.  Definitely not worth the money.  And I know it's not a huge deal, but they don't have free refills on soda.  For such an expensive place, that is remarkably stingy.  AMBIANCE The "island" is actually a boat -- as in, it's just floating there and can be motored about and such.  The upper deck has a little lighthouse and some foliage on it and a miniature white picket fence (it all reminded me of an elaborate mini golf hole), and below deck is where the restaurant is.    The restaurant below deck has some cool ambiance.  It's got pretty, dark wood molding on all the walls and lot of pictures everywhere in ornate gold frames, and the walls are all curved like the inside of a ship (which it is).  The restaurant was also much bigger than I was expecting, given how small and kitchy the top deck felt.  Also, when you hear that it's an island and that you'll need to catch the complimentary boat shuttle to the island, you picture a bit of a ferry ride taking you well out into the water.  This is not the case.  Forbes Island isn't out to sea at all.  It's right there situated amidst all the restaurants and shops and docks and such of Fisherman's Wharf.  There is actually a dock that extends out behind Forbes Island, which made us wonder why the shuttle boat was even necessary.  It seems as if you could just walk out there.  SEASICKNESS My husband and I both took two tablets of Dramamine roughly 40 minutes before getting on the "island", and I felt dizzy throughout dinner, and my husband started out dizzy and ended up nauseated by the time we left.    For context, I usually don't get seasick (out of lots of boat rides, I've been dizzy only once before and never bothered taking Dramamine before).  My husband has been nauseated on maybe 50% of the boat rides he's taken, which is why I made sure he took some Dramamine.  SERVICE When we arrived, the shuttle boat was just pulling up.  Both going to and returning from the island, the shuttle boat was captained by Forbes Thor Kiddoo himself, owner and builder of Forbes Island.  That guy could out deadpan anybody.  I just could not tell when he was joking and when he wasn't.  We waited on the shuttle boat ten minutes or so while other customers arrived.  The boat was not heated, so it was a very chilly wait and then a short, chilly ride.  When we got under way, we instantly arrived at Forbes Island.  It seriously is so close to land.  If you had a good arm, you could stand on the shore and hit Forbes Island with a football.  This made me wonder why our cold wait on the boat for other diners to arrive was necessary at all.    Furthermore, when we and 8 other diners arrived en masse at the restaurant, the space and waiters were not at all organized to deal with a bunch of different parties arriving at once, which must happen every shuttle arrival!  There wasn't an obvious host/hostess podium or waiting area or signs or anything.  We all just sort of crowded in out of the cold and stood in the middle of everything, not knowing what to do.  My husband and I got seated because I flagged down a waiter and asked if we were just supposed to seat ourselves or what.  After that, dinner service went fine.  Our waiter was competent and the food arrived in a timely fashion.  After dinner, there was a small, WARM room on the upper deck of Forbes Island with a fireplace where we could wait for the shuttle to go back.  And then it was a chilly ride back.

m-q18lAVSe6rKVLCpmebSQ.review_text: As much of a tourist trap as it may be, Forbes Island falls into the category of "I probably shouldn't yelp this, but..." type of truly special spots - even for locals. With 205 reviews though, I'd say the cat's out of the bag. This is one kitschy treasure of a tourist trap no SF resident should miss!   Find the designated phone and ring up the shuttle boat. You'll probably get picked up by good ol' Forbes Thor Kiddoo himself. I've never eaten dinner there, but I've found the fantastical surroundings to be just perfect for an adventurous happy hour with friends or quirky date-night drinks. The bar is under water and is decked out with a fireplace and every nautical novelty imaginable, there's a sandy faux beach up top, and there's a lighthouse that you can climb up inside of to check out the sea lions or bridge view if you're prepared to sway. You've just got to see it for yourself.   If you don't know the back story on Forbes and the island, it's definitely worth reading up on. It's a cool slice of SF history; that's for sure! Forbes built hundreds of floating homes in the Bay Area before constructing his own extravagant mobile mansion. The original version of Forbes Island was so posh, it was even featured on Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous! He then had some trouble with permits and turned it into a restaurant. I think those are the basics?  Landlubbers, try your best to not to fall victim to motion sickness... or pirates. Arrrrrr! And speaking of pirates, I've heard Forbes has a bountiful booty of pirate jokes up his sleeve!

Eo4iEYfKEyKVoNOzJdY2Rw.review_text: I'm on a boat! For realz. And I had no idea I was gonna be on a boat until I was actually on the boat....  Love love LOVE the concept, but apparently my queasy stomach doesn't like the reality. I don't typically get seasick, but I think it was a mixture of eating, drinking and being in a below-deck dimly lit cabin that did it for me.   Prices were a bit high, with the salmon being over $30 (it was Canadian and Organic, after all ;) ) so I went with the seafood soup (split with a colleague) and the crab and avocado appetizer. It was more than enough food for me, plus I was filling up on bread to help ease my not-so-happy stomach.  My martini was top-notch, though. Dirty martini has become my dinner drink of choice lately, and Forbes Island delivered. You can never go wrong with Grey Goose, right?  I do have to say that the sweet man who drove the water taxi was clearly proud of Forbes Island and truly made us feel welcome from the moment we stepped foot on the dock. He gave us a short history lesson and offered to act as a photographer, even arranging us in the perfect pose in front of the lighthouse while he got on the ground to capture the moment. That's dedication. And enthusiasm.  I think I just crossed "eating dinner on a public houseboat/restaurant in San Francisco" off my bucket list.

FtorTfN3VSflYx7iJghEKg.review_text: Fun place to take out of towners.  20,000 leagues feel to the place.  You pick up a phone near Pier 39 and a boat picks you up for dinner. Food is good but a little pricey. After dinner you can tour the lighthouse. I'd go back.

_D1EOOuuHqwxTzLOkFCr8g.review_text: Great place to eat when you are in SF!  Wait staff was superb and the food was excellent.  A truly unique experience...my kids said it reminded them of Mr. Crab's house (from the TV show, Sponge Bob Square Pants).  The underwater dining an lighthouse are really great.  Take the tour and you will get some of the best views of the SF Bay (Alcatraz, Pier 39 seals, Golden Gate Bridge).  I used to live in SF years ago and really did not experience this little gem of a restaurant.  A MUST dining experience.

kZJWAY828P8QZTqVYzhTCg.review_text: My first review of Forbes Island was written 8-9 years after I had actually dined there, so food details were more than foggy in my brain...they were non existent. My party of five (NOT the tv show) dined here this weekend to celebrate a birthday, so here comes the food lowdown (while it's still fresh in my memory):   My classic filet mignon ($39) was cooked just right--well done without being dry & the 'truffled bordelaise demi-glace' tasted like a (more concentrated) fine wine. Broccoli & shitake mushroom puff was like a quiche, tasty but a little salty. The tiny potatoes (three kinds!) were perfect with the steak.   Our bruchetta w/ avocado appetizer was delicious. Bread was toasted, but still soft-ish, balsamic was sharp & the tomatoes were well-seasoned.   For dessert, I went with something I NEVER fancy---an apple tarte tatin with an awesomely thick rum caramel sauce & a thick whipped cream. Highly recommended!   I stole a few bites of bf's food: flat iron steak & potato purée was very good, although I think the mustard cognac creme sauce was a little too 'strong' for his liking. And a few bites of my mom's dessert: the berry parfait-- so simple but very good.   Other dishes our party ordered: braised short ribs, soup du jour was red pepper, & a crab, avocado & scallop salad--all winners.  (sidenote: I was quite thirsty & a little headachy after our meal, probably due to its high sodium content. Salt-tards beware!)   Still love eating on a floating island. If you're prone to sea sickness, take a Dramamine 2 hours before dining here.

9HskxgFFZf2At2UpL5QkPQ.review_text: I *loved* everything about this place and did not want to LEAVE the island. sniff. So much fun, and great food and wine too. I did not get a bit seasick, guess I've got good sea legs?

OGUrVZTPcWhtQBwISbNUGw.review_text: What can I say, this is the best restaurant I have ever been to. Starting from the boat ride and the driver, very nice, the staff OUTSTANDING. Our frenchy bartender makes a great manhattan, our waiter was all around customer service oriented. All the staff have been trained in professionalism...and it shows. No one addressed our table as (what can I get you guys). Which, nowadays is very common and rude. Especially since we are ladies. I don't think I got our waiters name, we were there on Xmas eve. I had the lamb pops medium rare...OUTSTANDING my partner had the lobster risotto  OUTSTANDING as well. We talked to the bartender about renting the island for a party, can't wait for that to come to life. It's nice to go to a place that has such wonderful customer service. We will return, everything was outstanding, thank you Mr. Forbes, for keeping the bar high and not lowering standards. Joy

oUNm5rDUDxu0LMximnNHWQ.review_text: Yes - this is a two-fer - I already reviewed the Yelp party...   I went to a stella Yelp event here with Yelp's own *original* Pirate, Andi T - thanks to Yelp, Ruggy, and the fab Jessica for puttin' it on for us.  What's not to like - the rum cocktails were delish and the lines short - and the mostly veggie snacks were as good as any such shindig or chantey I have been to.  Forbes Island is a treat for all - pirates and lubbers alike. Aside from the splendid vitals, there are lower quarters, decked out like a ship (with a bar and tables), a "real" lighthouse with spectacular views, and a wheelhouse (for Forbes is a floating island, equipped with the largest outboard motor ever made, fresh from WWII).  And it;s packed, every inch of wall and room, with nautical and historical memorbilia - plenty for any scurvy chum to spend a charming afternoon or evening relaxing by the bay!  I would recommend you set sail for The Island sometime - and ask yer boatman, Mr. Forbes himself, for a brief history of how she came to be in such a lucky location!   Haaar!

jiJgNstuSDenJl0n7xs26A.review_text: I ate here for dine about town last week with one of my bffs, and we had a blast! the leek and potato soup was creamy and delicious! my flat iron steak was cooked perfectly! the scalloped potatoes were seasoned nicely.. i ordered an arnold palmer, it seems that they used lime juice instead or lemon.. kind of weird i must say, but its okay because the dessertss certainly made up for it! I am in love with the berries and marscapone!!! it came with a crunchy toffee cookie and the chocolate mousse was soo rich, but also very light, the crust tasted like crushed ferrero roche candies, my favorite!! i liked it there, probably wont go back because ive experienced it and its checked off on my list as a good one!!!

kXAmIzA3o8HW42vfCTjj5Q.review_text: I enjoyed the food.  The boat rocked more than most people expected, but it did not bother me.  Nice 'unique' dining experience.  Romantic'ish, but a little hokey.  Still would recommend but be prepared for it to be a mini adventure.  The dessert was not so yummy, so be warned about getting the creme brulee if you do not like ginger.  They added a lot of it! (It is in the description)  Pricey, but great views, so understandable. 8xlWSLLEaSQpaJIPRq4yBA.review_text: Ate dinner here last night and it was a perfect place to celebrate a birthday! The food was pricey but worth it for the experience. 98ddzTqAKldnPNFUJhqopw.review_text: My husband proposed to me here nearly 5 years ago. It was magical and not just because of the new jewelry! ltb_FEBEf2-PuPqQQ4aSHg.review_text: Service was excellent (which is the main reason for 2 stars and not 1), scenery at the lighthouse was amazing but my problem with this restaurant is that the food was extremely extremely salty. I'm not sure if it was just an off night for the chef but unfortunately it was pretty much unbearable.  I took my boyfriend here for his birthday and I was super excited for two weeks before the big night but the food ruined the experience for us. We ordered the clam chowder, avocado bruschetta, potatoes au gratin, a fish entree, and the duck - and all were too salty except for the duck meat. Even the potato purée was loaded with salt! I would give it another try but for that price, I wouldn't chance it.

Oo7weCiN2wFfZrgY4FZbaQ.review_text: visited again this year in Oct. as good as i remembered. loved the taste of appetizers and Berries Napoleon. wished appetizer portion can be a little bit bigger though.

Wc5L6iuvSNF5WGBlqIO8nw.review_text: I can't speak to the food, though there were quiet moans of I think yum from my hungry companions. n6GBeJVd1C2dszlSOBAfJw.review_text: A group of us (10) came here for the dinner to experience dinner on an island/boat, underwater, and fireworks. We were starving by the time we got there since we walked around the pier for a while before getting on the boat that takes us to the island. Waited for the boat and met Captain Forbes. He is super nice and funny. Explains to us the history of the island and how a seal wiggled himself on his boat.  The island looked romantic with the lighthouse and everything. I was hoping to be seated downstairs under water but our party was too big to be down there so we were seated upstairs. That was OK though since the firework display was right in front of us.  After getting seated, we all just either went to the bathroom since one had motion sickness after drinking too, some went to explore, and some went to the lighthouse and took pictures. Super awesome view but too much stairs and it was such a windy evening, I thought I was gonna get blown away off into the sea by the wind.  Started to look at the menu and the choices were limited for $65 but still offered soup or salad, and entrees that include chicken, steak, salmon, and risotto, and two different desserts.   I of course chose the Crab Bisque Pan Seared Flat Iron Steak: Porcini Mushroom Crème Sauce, Scalloped Potatoes & Green Beans Chocolate Mousse: Hazelnut & Pecan Crust Cake topped with Whipped Crème  Crab bisque was serve lukewarm, not good but came with lots of crab meat. Flat iron steak was really good an cooked perfectly. Big portion and the scalloped potatoes were so good. crispy top! Just how I like it. The porcini mushroom sauce was way to heavy and taste like they used 100lb of butta! Chocolate mousse was good but way too decadent but the hazelnut and pecan crust was amazing yummy.   (I tried the Organic Pan Roasted Salmon: Cilantro Pesto Rice, Sautéed Spinach & Ginger Lime Crème Sauce. This was so awful. Tasted only ginger and the salmon was super dry!)  I only wish I hadn't of stuffed myself with bread and butter so that I can at least eat more then 2-3 pieces of steak!  We were served by Eve and she gave us probably one of the best service I've ever experienced. Super nice and very apologetic when it came to us having to pay $200 just for corkage on two Remy bottles! You kidding me! Friend called and ask about the corkage and they said $25 flat fee and when we brought the bottle out, stupid, owner/manager said it's $200! Crazy! But Eve was nice and just kept apologizing about the situation....  My experience this one time is probably enough and I wouldn't come back

hGsLDk8zhgZiTsHYsazLXA.review_text: I loved this place. The captain, aka FORBES himself picks you up on a boat at Pier 39. Takes you a hop skip and a jump (to the breakwater) to get to his island. Which used to be his home. In Sausalito until they booted him out 15 years ago. He replaced his palm trees he had then with a cool lighthouse. 55 steps to get to the top. NIce views of Angel Island.  And SF Bay too, of course. You hear the sea lions "serenading" you (fautrever.com/videos/200…), until you get inside the restaurant. It is very warm and cozy. And they have rooms you can reserve for your whole party. Pretty cool. There are port holes all around and you are actually part way under water. The light fixtures sway a little, but you won't notice that much. Casey was our waiter. He was so attentive and cute too! I had Avocado,olive and tomato bruschetta for an appetizer. Hubby had seafood chowder. NIce presentation. It was quite tasty for both items. For dinner, hubby had chicken and i had Risotto with mushrooms, zucchini and onions. YUMMY! We had a really nice wine too. Then, for dessert, Ginger Vanilla creme brulee. With a candle. And the waiter gave me a rose since it was my birthday. I personally believe this restaurant is for adults mainly,but, if I had a 16 year old daughter, she would LOVE IT! I loved it. The couple next to us loved it and were celebrating a birthday too. (hey, I think they should get married. Cute couple. Carlo and Sofia!) The prices are high, but hey, go two times a year, splurge have fun! Well, anyways, we are very glad we went here. We lived in the BAy Area for years and never went. We will be back. A nice event! Great place. they validate parking too.

2ihE2wYubE6p_gaoWQ_maQ.review_text: FYI: Forbes Island is a boat which has tons of weight added to it in order to be lower in the water.  The inside was turned into a restaurant.  You will ride a small boat, with Forbes as your driver, over to the "island" (AKA floating boat).  Forbes is incredibly down to earth and uber friendly.  I do get mild motion sickness/sea sickness, but I was fine here.  The waters were calm though, and I heard it can be more rough and can move you more if big ships pass by. There is a small lighthouse there too.  After dinner Forbes was sitting there in a deck chair chatting with us.  He is super cool and very non pretentious!    *TIP*- If you want a really romantic dinner that not everyone knows about...They have a 3,000 bottle wine cellar on the boat/island.  You can make a reservation for the table-for-two IN the wine cellar. Very cool!    Food: Cost- Two of us ate for approximately $120 with tip included. You don't get five star dining type food; i think the price is more indicative of the "novelty" of it all. It was worth it for a one-time experience.  I would take others there for sure.    Flavor/Taste- I had the Flank Steak, and it was "ok".  I ordered it medium.  It didn't appear to be cooked that way, but it was dark in there.  It was good.  Service: Our server was great!  We had one main server, but we also were tag teamed with a second server; they were both great.  Negative: The night we went was a weekday.  It was apparently "kids night" (No, there really isn't a kids night...but it might as well have been chuck e cheese  LOL) on Forbes Island.  We were surrounded by children.  No lie!  There were at least seven children within earshot of us.  In addition to that, there was another table of 8 or so folks having a grand time.  It was not the easiest to hear while talking.  *These issues were likely an isolated occurrence and not the norm, but frustrating nonetheless.

Q5zxztnhEqgrpmLbuH0e0A.review_text: I was in San Fran for a weekend and wanted to take a friend to dinner. Forbes Island was recommended to me. After reading the description I was willing to bet that I was in for some kitschy restaurant with bad food but the Yelp reviews said otherwise. Boy were they wrong. I agree that the set-up is unique but there are some things that anyone who dines there should know. #1 - the barge rocks and there are no windows so you start to feel a bit queasy, especially after a few glasses of wine #2 - the food is not very good, in fact it is quite bad. everything was loaded with pepper and the fish was way overdone and dry (both the salmon and the sea bass) #3 - the wine is nice and well priced (+1 star) #4 - the view from the top of the light house is nice  In a city such as san fran which has incredible restaurants, I would never recommend that anyone waste their time eating here. Wyi-aMgoLNacGYoRHGkNrg.review_text: My family of 5 went here for my mom's birthday and it was great!!  Food and service was incredible.  My mom and I had the salmon and it was delicious. 2yC0uqrLDDPaSbhXBWonEA.review_text: Had a very good experience for my first visit. It was definitely something different and the staff are very friendly. 1sqvXZOrheicKnyMSnHxTQ.review_text: I wanted to find a romantic place to tell my girlfriend that I love her and this place was perfect! vZSm2ZFO0ryY1kh4EvNQig.review_text: You can't beat a private candle light dinner in someone's wine room or scoring a cozy table by the fire in the "living room". RgDVC3ZUBqpEe6Y1kPhIpw.review_text: Getting here alone is a spectacle. An adventure. An exploration into the tourist trodden Fisherman's Wharf. Off in the misty, dark-sky distance, your eyes land upon a beacon of light projecting from a lighthouse.   Beneath the lighthouse there seems to be a house. But not just any house. This decorous houseboat seems to blend true house with boat. And then you learn, it used to be Forbes' house that's since been set afloat.   Before you actually get there though, you have to find the phone that offers a direct line of contact between the dock on Fisherman's Wharf and the bartender awaiting you on Forbes Island (a somewhat decadent house on a barge with a lighthouse that functions as a restaurant and modestly-stooled bar).  Once the call is made, a transit boat will arrive to offer complimentary transport to this often-overlooked dining mine.  Once you arrive, you'll be tickled to know you can actually hike up the circular stairwell to the top of the lighthouse for a 360-degree view of SF (yes, you can see the lights of Alcatraz), you'll be able to use the restroom in the regal dormitory that Forbes once occupied (yes, you can lay on the bed), you'll pay attention to the varying ambiance throughout (either bask on the deck on some chaise loungers or scurry inside to the kingly dining room with ever-swaying chandeliers). Anyway you slice it, Forbes Island is an experience unlike any other.  The best part, Forbes will often be your boat captain. Make sure to ask whether he's been married.

Fc_D-qKdOjt5hcvxifKFCQ.review_text: "No wonder we are not still together!"  I've been here twice and there's no way in the world I'll go again.   PBS Restaurant show did a review on Forbes and it was bad. Overpriced, pretentious and not worth it.   This is one of those pretentious places that women especially love to say they've been too, and guys don't say anything but cringe every time they realize how much they've spent.  P.S. remember this is a man made boat dock.  The Boat rocks back and forth at times which is kind of strange.   The first time I went the boat was so hot we were sweating the whole time.  It was so uncomfortable.    The food was in portions that would not feed a bird, and for unreal prices.    Someone had given us a great bottle of wine; very expensive, and the corkage fee was $25 which is getting to be the norm.   On each occasion we went home hungry and ate a couple of hours later.   The food was pretty good, just in portions that were comical.   The short ribs were juicy but a little fatty and the portion was ridiculously small.    I love salmon but the sauce with spinach and ginger battled with the flavor of the salmon and didn't go with it.    The entrees are $28-39 and the servings are a joke to be honest.  I've been to the french laundry and their servings are very small but there are several courses.   For desserts we had creme brulee and I'm not kidding; it could not have been a 1/2 inch thick.  We laughed at the end because my girlfriend knew I wasn't happy about spending so much for such a crappy meal.  We had pizza later that night.   Pro's: Nice place; atmosphere; but it's overrated at times; at night it's flat out freezing so you cant' stay out on the lighthouse long anyway.  Nice wine list even though it's a huge markup.  Con's Ridiculous pricing; bird size portions, ship is hot in the summer.   I would not go there again.  The most overrated and overpriced tourist traps I've ever been to.   Every woman wants to go there; every guy dreads it.

-LQKZqMsswhkM-Qia70coA.review_text: Reading all the overwhelmingly good reviews we where a tad bit disappointed, especially with the food that wasn't more than a fraction above mediocre. Bit of a tourist trap. One thing earn them a 5 star rating though, the absolutely fantastic staff delivering a friendly and splendid service.

_hZnHWlabEMjg58YQpQWHQ.review_text: I took my boyfriend here as a surprise and it was a lot of fun.   When arriving you use the phone to alert the restaurant that you have arrived for your reservation. They ask that you sit and await the small boat to arrive and take you to the island. you walk down the ramp to a little waiting area with an island feel (small palm trees aligned and a few bench seats).   When the boat arrives to pick you up, make note that this is a man made island and the owner is the one getting you to your destination. The boat is enclosed, so you wont get wet if it's raining out. When you arrive at the island, you are encouraged to explore the light house and other areas of the island as you will be dining below water.   The food and wine is delicious, and the wait staff is happy to make recommendations. one thing to note, the island sways a bit while you are dining, so this is not the place for you if you get sea sick.

X7NruZXmLRCXnYpa6ylwRg.review_text: Forbes Island is one of the those places that is an out of the ordinary dining experience but you don't necessarily go all the way out there for the food.  It is a man-made island floating just outside of Pier 39. The owner Mr. Forbes Kiddoo captains his boat to take you to the island himself. (At least this was the case about six years ago.) Catchy huh?  Once you arrive on the island, you can do a little tour with the main attraction being the lighthouse. There is an upper level dining room reserved for private parties. The dining room itself is submerged under water and fashioned like a large yacht.   The food quality is not bad but the experience is more of the selling point. It has been over 6 years since I have been here so please don't hold me to it.

OGPjzbR79rl6PczRfq5C6A.review_text: We recently had a company event at Forbes Island.  What a fun experience that was!!!   Casey and all of the staff did a wonderful job to making it a memorable event!  We had the event on a Thursday night and we couldn't have asked for better weather and sea lions were also there to give us a big welcome on the ferry ride over.  I would highly recommend the Forbes Island experience to everyone and it is a great place for a company event.   Oh and if you like martini's make sure to ask Casey to shake it 40 times, no more, no less!!! :)

ctIQb8seZY1UQXt9jbcfXg.review_text: What an incredible experience!  I had a VERY last minute dinner party in mind for my husband's birthday.  With only 3 days advanced warning, Casey went to work.  When we arrived, Dakota was  our own personal waiter for our event.  It was absolutely seamless from the time our party arrived to when we left.  It's as if I had planned it weeks in advance.  The room was beautiful when we arrived; the candles lit, roses on the tables and the bar was ready.  For any special event or simply to treat yourself, you won't be disappointed.  Our party was a huge success.  Many, many thanks again to Casey, Dakota and staff.

PSBZweYyW_KrOkv9RZHKUg.review_text: I visited Forbes Island on a whim to get drinks at the bar.  I was playing tourist in my own city. And after walking around Pier 39, I finally decided to go to that floating island.  We didn't have any reservations and called ahead to see if we could sit at the bar.  After walking to a small gate between Pier 39 and 41, we picked up a phone and dialed for our Captain to come pick us up.  We waited only minutes before a boat came and picked us up and about 2 minutes later, we were at Forbes Island.  The whole experience was absolutely unique.  Our Captain gave us a tour of the island...after looking closely at some old photos in frames across the restaurant wall, we quickly realized that our Captain was the owner of the restaurant.    The bar is rather small and intimate and seats about 8 people. But the bartender was very friendly and told us all the history of the floating island. The restaurant is also very intimate and filled with mostly couples or families.  This would be a great place to take your mother for a birthday dinner or go on a romantic date. I only gave 4 stars since I didn't actually eat any food.  But I definitely plan on going back and making a reservation soon!

BIpISrUNSKLA8EDKhFJyyQ.review_text: Such a great experience!  I'm so glad my boyfriend surprised me with this place for our anniversary because it's definitely a worthwhile experience for everyone to try... except for those who are aware they get motion sickness.  It's pretty fun to take the shuttle boat to the one and only floating island. The decorations for the island is cool. Once you dock, the captain leads you down the stairs to the restaurant.  The service is great. Our waiter was friendly and checked in on us a lot. The other servers were just as good.  Since the island is floating, you can actually feel the place swaying every now and then. I tried not to think too much about it and focused on eating and chatting to avoid getting motion sickness. It's honestly not too bad, but might be during poor weather conditions.  The food is nothing spectacular but there's still some parts of my meal that's memorable for me.  My recommendations: - Dungeness crab, avocado & bay scallop salad: avocado tasted fresh, baby tomatoes were yummy with the orange/citrus fennel vinaigrette. The vinaigrette for this salad was absolutely delicious. I loved it. - Potato puree: the mash potatoes were so good. Nice, creamy and fluffy. You can order this as a side to go with your entree.  For the entrees, we ordered the Pan Seared Flat Iron Steak and the Slow Braised Short Ribs. If I ever come again, I don't think I'm going to get these entrees again. Instead I would try something new like the salmon or filet mignon. The steak and short ribs tasted good, but not fantastic. The portions for the entrees though were bigger than I expected.  I ordered the gelato for dessert. It was okay, but I should've got fresh berries to go with it. I would suggest ordering another dessert.  After our dinner, we walked around the island. There's very nice views of the Bay Bridge and SF. We even got to go on top of their lighthouse to see an even better view. It says "No smoking," but people still smoked!  We had to wait a while before the shuttle boat came to take us back to Pier 41. It's not that big of a deal though because we kept ourselves busy by looking around the island and taking pictures.  My boyfriend and I got really thirsty for the rest of the night after we ate here though. But I would still recommend this place because it's a fun experience to have.

wOpMzUOLbTVxY2lKD3B3jw.review_text: It was fun taking the boat to the island and the service all around was great. The food was excellent (we ahi tuna and avocado bruschetta, lamb lollipops and filets). The restaurant was very cool and we had a blast. Will be back to this place!

hbtbV_GzExqIH6gcGOXNIA.review_text: I booked one of the Forbes Island dining rooms for the hubby's 40th birthday, and it was a smash success!  Casey was extremely helpful in outlining all of the options. 1CU3jr9NlSQ2rbYxEM1Yow.review_text: Took my wife to Forbes Island for her birthday dinner and this place really hit the spot. We don't usually travel to the city to eat but this place made the trip well worthwhile. It was very unique in the sense that nobody could walk up to it like at Pier 39 restaurants so it almost has that secluded effect on you at night since it's only people that are eating there that can get to it. The guy that runs the Shuttle was really cool, Gave us all a break down on how Forbes Island came about and the history behind it. From there you continue on a minute and 30 second ride or so to the barge, Yes I said barge because that's what it's built on and he directs you to your dining area. The dining area was really cool, If you are claustrophobic it may not be the best idea to eat here as there aren't really very many windows and the aisles are sort of tiny to walk down but I am and I made it through the meal fine. I read some of the reviews on here prior to going and I guess depending on how important you think you are you may find the service bad or a notice a dirty fork but all in all if you are a sensible human being and don't need the celebrity treatment for the money you spend and are capable of walking too and from the shuttle and also willing to communicate with the waiter/waitress if you need new silverware you should be just fine.

kso4kcbgVTGRJDEwZkMjzg.review_text: I came here with my girlfriend this past Valentine's Day. It's very exciting to ride across in a boat to the restaurant... which is actually another boat! A+++ for unique experience and ambiance. The actually restaurant is a lot bigger than it looks, due to the fact that a large portion of it is actually under water! There are little portholes you can look through... although you probably won't see much, the water is murky.  Very classy place, the menu was a Prix Fix for V-Day that started off with an excellent crab bisque. We then each had some sort of salad with a vinaigrette dressing that wasn't bad, but unmemorable. My girlfriend had the halibut and I had some sort of steak... both were good, the portions were huge! Mind you... we were also filling up on delicious Belvedere Pomegranate Martinis and other such extravagant and unnecessary cocktails... especially for being on a boat! Which leads me to my next point. You can feel the boat rocking! Kudos to the servers for totally handling it as the ship swayed back and forth. I was starting to feel slightly sea sick at one point, but surprisingly drinking alcohol HELPED.  There are a lot of cool little rooms you can explore on the "Island", such as the "Captains Quarters" which sports a bed, piano and everything! The bathroom has a walk in shower... which makes me believe someone DOES (perhaps the actual captain?!) or used to permanently stay there... or I guess all of it could be for show.  Outside you can actually climb the lighthouse and catch the view, which is nice... but in 6" spiked heels I didn't want to stay up there for too long with the heavy winds (and previous heavy alcohol and food consumption). My only complaint was that we had researched the menu online and they had never updated it from the previous Valentine's Day, and there were a lot more options on last year's menu. I'd try it again...

f1o96a1Q4Sno_RBjU6Jayw.review_text: This place is incredible.  It's extremely novel; beautiful location and ambiance, a lighthouse that takes your breath away, unique decor, EXCELLENT SERVICE and to top it off, the food is great.  I really enjoyed the 'experience' of it all, this is a great place to take a date or have an event.  I happened to order too much and was full after appetizers....I asked him to pack up my $20 entree for me and he did so, but not before removing the entree from the bill.  To me, this says so much about the level of service and consideration.   The only reason I'm not giving this 5 stars is because of the rocking.  Come equipped with anti-nausea or seasickness pills, or make sure you stare at the light fixture if down below.  Also, most of the time it's very cold so bring a thick coat and scarf.   Ladies, make sure you check out the bathroom.  I don't want to spoil the surprise, but I think I can guarantee you've never seen anything quite like it.  It's almost worth the visit just to see the bathroom!  (In a good way :)

pBRMkVKpAWvnwqGIA9v7og.review_text: The Island and its staff are fantastic.  We had our wedding there this season, and everyone was very accomodating--before, during, and after the event.    Forbes was a gentleman, Casey was super, Pierre was great, and Trish and Estaban were fantastic.    The Forbes Island team provided superior service, great patience, helpful suggestions, and true effort.  Moreover, their positivity was really appreciated.  This is in addition to the beautiful views, classy dining room, and fun, intimate and charming venue to relax and enjoy.  We'll definitely, definitely be back and encourage you to visit Forbes Island, too! 2AcBFhqPOXcCbUEvCQr5bA.review_text: I was very SF snob when a visiting friend suggested we hit Forbes Island up.  I had to eat crow when I discovered how cute it really was and how much fun it could be.  I don't recommend going on a windy night as you may 'loose your lunch' at the table, but I really enjoyed watching little fish swim by the port hole windows near our table. hrW0lH_ce9BYlfXwqpoHlA.review_text: So I decided to take my G/F here for a romantic dinner. 0oSXrux_1FZtw3TAZ0ExTA.review_text: Simply awesome. Forbes is a cool character and his island is the perfect venue for a unique and fun dinner experience in the city.   Can't wait to go back!!!    :D

EohLvLo87M2GNbYGL-AlUA.review_text: Holy romance Batman!! This restaurant is where it is at if you are looking for a nice night out with SO. They have atmosphere coming out the wazoo.   You start off by taking a nice boat ride to their floating boat island! Yeah you heard me right...this restaurant is on a boat just floating along out there. So it's definitely an experience. Once there you go down below deck to an small intimate dining space. It's very darkly lit, and has a fireplace and little windows where you can occasionally see fish swimming around. Or in our case one fish just staring at the window for the whole two hours we were there.   You should know that sometimes you will feel weird, since the boat is kind of rocking around. I had a weird reaction to it but it wasn't that bad.   Our server was very attentive and helpful. She made some great suggestions, and immediately offered to replace my drink when she noticed I wasn't drinking it.   The food was also very good. I got the salmon and thought it was cooked very well. I really really loved the sauce that came with it.   While there I saw a wedding party show up, and a man who I'm pretty sure was about to propose to his girlfriend...like I said super romantic. I feel like it is something that everyone should experience once while at the pier. I mean as far as touristy things go, eating delicious dinner in a floating boat island is pretty great!  Also you can go upstairs to their attached lighthouse after dinner. It has a great view of the city and it also super cute.

k94WrtXfHaMBa3i35q66QA.review_text: I'd been looking forward to coming here since before I moved here and when I went I wasn't let down.  - Very small menu but good food.  - Never a wait because they require reservations.  - Amazing service.

2wlxmrRa-PTbaGgReRUxDw.review_text: WOW!!!!  This place is an absolute must see and certainly a hidden gem in San Fran.  Located just off pier 39, this tiny man made island was once the home to the wealthy Forbes Kiddoo.  (Who actually captains the boat out to the island).  After a brief introduction and an even briefer boat ride you arrive on the tiny little tucked away treasure of Forbes Island.  After a small view of the place, Mr. Forbes directs you to your dining room where your stomach and eyes shall leave happy.    The galley (fashioned as a yacht hull) is filled with classic maritime tokens and treasures such as muskets, swords, paintings, model ships, etc.   It also has portholes to view out into the bay and watch the fish swim by.  But the real jewel and treasure lies in the food.  The special of the evening was Sea Bass in a potato puree and a beautifully delicate and tasty tarragon sauce.  YOWZA! the sea bass was perfectly tender and delicate and the potatoes were lightly salted and garlic butter to perfection.  My pal got the eggplant risotto and it was such a great balance between delicate and hearty my mouth melted.    Our server was also super super sweet and we never once thought to look for her, she was already there.  After dinner, a trip the lighthouse is in order giving a beautiful view of Pier 39's sea lions as well as the hilly San Fran streets.  Overall a beautiful place with great food, atmosphere, service and location.

vRziAXWI72nOFWNml4ldMA.review_text: Took my fiance here for Valentines day to try something different. Overall we had a great experience. The one thing that stood out was the service was really great. It's cool experience taking the little boat to the bigger island boat. then being seated down below. The place definitely rocks so if you're prone to sea sickness it's something to be aware of.  We had a leisurely dinner and next time we'll probably grab our coctails and head up top afterwards and hang out on the deck where they have chairs and enjoy the evening. We also checked out the light house that we walked to the top which was nice.  The food was good. Didn't blow me away but it was good. Place gets 4 stars still since it's just a really pleasant experience.

KJ_0tYPk3VeoNun0s4RkBA.review_text: Captain Scruffy, I love you.  Forbes Island is the most magical and amazing place in San Francisco. Here are some reasons why:  1) You take a boat to the "Island" restaurant. The boat is driven by NONE OTHER than Captain Scruffy, who we discovered, is Forbes himself. He built the island. And lived on the island/floating house for years.   2) Captain Scruffy (Forbes, come on people), is perhaps the sweetest, cutest old man I've ever met. Think a kinder, more lovable professor from Gilligans Island.  3) The Island is complete with a lighthouse, which makes for memorable and beautiful San Francisco night views.   4) The Seals. Ohhhh the seals. As one of the people in my group who happens to be obsessed with seals said, "they just want hugs and kisses," as we sailed away from Forbes, listening to the Seal's night calls.  5) The rocking of the "boat:" Yes, during dinner, a few times, people in my group pondered how screwed we would be if a monsoon were to strike. We enjoyed our dinner while simultaneously enduring the storm winds.  Initially, I went into this whole experience assuming Forbes Island was a fun and unique tourist trap. While it is extremely fun and oh so unique, it is certainly not a tourist trap. In fact, as our waitress explained, many locals in San Francisco come to Forbes (many of whom didn't know it existed before, like us).   And I must say, the food was very good. I had a perfectly dressed mixed greens salad with pickled onions, a lovely medium rare flank steak with a mustard sauce and potatoes au gratin, and a delightfully sweet chocolate mousse cake with hazelnut crust and fresh whipped cream.   Our waitress was incredibly knowledgeable about the history of Forbes Island and her enthusiasm for the special place only made our adventure at sea more memorable.   I can't wait to sail away to Forbes Island again, hopefully soon. I will bring more friends this time to share this perfect "only in San Francisco" experience with.

jOMnQTm_iewXffyjzw5Tjg.review_text: The food and service at this place are absolutely amazing!! I had the salmon and my gf had the rack of lamb. 3k27FlGRtQRURGZtLo6ZMQ.review_text: It was an odd experience.  It is right in the heart of Fisherman's Wharf and has a very touristy gimmick going on.  You take a boat to get there but that just feels silly.  It's so close and they could literally build a bridge and spare you the 3 minute ride on a beaten down boat.  The food is much too expensive for what it is but is at least edible.  The restaurant makes you feel sea sick and rocks whenever a large boat passes it by.  The space is pretty dark and cold because it is under the water.  I did like the lighthouse and the view you can see from 50 stairs up.  They also give you a free postcard to send out and the staff is extremely friendly.  If you don't get motion sick, this is the place for you!

DZEH-wuHUfvA-PyBW3sXxA.review_text: Its really romantic. Its great for a date with some special. I went  there on a first date with someone...i was completely impressed, and not just with Forbes Island..but with the guy. But Forbes Island is really cute and romantic.

4vCqaT0F3RNpXMoOT9airg.review_text: I first noticed Forbes Island when I was pregnant with my daughter and, after dinner at Joe's Crab Shack, noticed something super-cool while walking near Pier 39.  I am a proud Bay Area Native.  Being from Redwood City, I especially love the Bay, though not necessarily Pier 39 and other tourist drudgery.  I looked into Forbes Island and was delighted to discover it was created by a famous Yacht Architect as a house boat that he lived in in Marin until a few years ago.  He decided to make into a restaurant off Pier 39 and the rest is history (or you can look it up yourself, LAZY!)  Anyway, it was almost Valentines Day and I mentioned to my friend Kat I wanted to go there.  Turns out she had her wedding dinner there and LOVES the place.  Raina was only a few months old, got a sitter and off we are on one of our first outings in months.  YAY!  We started with the short boat ride to the "island" which is awesome because being in this area makes you want to go on a boat, even if it's a short ride.  When we got there they started leading us to the dining room below deck, and we asked if we could stay above-ground.  I can't believe I am sharing this, and I hope it doesn't ruin our next trip, because out of four visits our preference if by far above-water.  The main dining room is in the main part of the boat below water.  There is two small twin dining areas above-deck, that seat (and this is probably a bad guess) 12?, 16?  The best parts are the (A) Views!:  You can see 360 degrees total, and the view of the actual city of SF (with my terrible math estimates) is well over 180 degrees.  Then there is (B) Privacy: granted, this is where the guests arriving or leaving on the boat gather, but in between those trips you have a good-sized dining room to yourselves.  The dining room has a fireplace, a sliding door out to the beach (albeit "fake"), and amazing views of SF, the lighthouse, and the sea lions.  You know what?  Dining above ground sucks!  I would HATE this review to stop anyone from eating in the main dining area (cuz that might fuck up are next trip there!)  I think the food is AMAZING.  Granted, I am not an SF food snob, but I know what I like.  I have been here 3 times now, and my favorite is the Filet Mignon with Truffle Sauce and some kind of Shitake Mushroom/cheese/broccoli souffle.  We have liked everything that we have eaten here, but this is by far our favorite, and it is consistently on the menu.  In a normal, boring restaurant, I wouldn't want to pay more that $20-$30 for this meal (or ANY meal), but when you are somewhere this amazing, I think the $39 is definitely worth it.  People Yelp about the price, but they "guess" it is okay, given the atmosphere, blah, blah, blah.  Well, I'd love to know of a better SF experience?  Where else could you have such an amazing view?  The amazing boat ride over?  The delicious food?  Oh, and I haven't even MENTIONED the lighthouse yet.  An amazing man-made lighthouse that you can climb up to further enjoy the view and the novelty of the restaurant.    The more I write this, the more I hope you pay attention to the "douche" who calls anyone who would give Forbes Island 5 stars a "douche".  I hope all of you out there will decide to pay attention to his reviews and spend your money on what he considers amazing food and ambience.  Forbes Island may have all of the makings of a tourist trap, and as a born and raised Bay Area native I want it to be all mine.  Did I mention how awesome it is to use the loo and find you get to go through the Captain's Quarters into his personal bathroom?  Did I mention how beautiful this place is, with views, decor, you name it?   P.S. Wow, the 3-star review where the guy wrote that anyone who gave it a 5-star review is a "deprived douche" or something of that effect is probably the first review that has ever made me angry.  I don't want to waste too much time on it, but he is one of those awful-douches whose profile says he is from "San Francisco", yet it is clear from his reviews he lives in the San Mateo/Burlingame area.  Hey, dude, go back to whatever OTHER place that you are form, because true Bay Area natives are a true (and unforgiving towards douche-bags) critic.

U8MN8gvl3OLnpC5EURTrnw.review_text: First of all, if you get seasick don't come here. My girlfriend and I don't but we saw someone else who probably wasn't having a great time for that.  I took my girlfriend here for Valentine's day and it was great. The boat captain was friendly as well as all of the restaurant staff. The food was absolutely AMAZING. This review is late but we got some sort of pot roast and rice dish with crab plus dessert which I still remember very vividly now and all were to die for. jNsPTMmg9EcqY7q2Q-Rm6A.review_text: This year, I celebrated Mother's Day with my mom a week early... because I'll be in Vegas. (sorry mom!) When I asked my mom if she had anywhere in particular she wanted to eat at, she mentioned Forbes Island. She then asked me if I had ever heard of it, I said no, and she said, LOOK IT UP WHEN YOU GET HOME! Fast forward to Sunday, the day we were going to eat here - she must have asked me about 5 times if I had looked it up. In my head I kept thinking, ok, I get it, we're going to a restaurant, but why do you keep asking me if I've looked it up (cause I hadn't).  When we get to Pier 39, parked, and walked towards the pier and I saw Forbes Island, I realized that I had noticed Forbes Island before from the pier and was curious about it. I still remember seeing it and thinking, well that's interesting! And, how do you get over there? When I realized this, I understood why my mom kept asking me if I had looked up the restaurant - because it is out of the ordinary.  When we got to the pier, others were boarding the shuttle so we just followed. The boat ride over to Forbes Island is less than a few minutes, but I enjoyed it a lot - it's been awhile since I've been on a boat! Once we arrived at the island, I was immediately curious to see the rest.   The island is very neat - fun to explore around for a bit, the dining room is also cool - very thematic which makes it a unique experience. The women's restroom on the dining level is also a fun aspect of the place - when you walk in, it looks like a captain's quarter, with a bed, functioning shower, sink, and toilet. Neat!  What's even better on top of everything is that the service, food, and drinks are great. The 5 of us ordered the Salmon, Petrale Sole (seafood special for the night), Skirt Steak, Chicken, and Chocolate Mousse. The seafood was very fresh, cooked right, and sauces were delicious. nJp0oN1v8tKjYFGToNT0-A.review_text: We had a great time at Forbes Island.  Myself and another friend had a joint birthday party and we rented out the entire island.  Casey and the staff were very helpful in planning the event and their service at the event was fantastic.  They went out of their way to make sure we had a great night. Bezh6tDmCrL0-SnsV6CneA.review_text: I had dinner with a high school friend here last time I visited SF. The "island" definitely lived up to its hype. Forbes Island is actually a manmade island right off the Pier (can't remember the number). You have to find the Island's dock and Forbes actually ferries you out. The island is pretty close to the pier.   This place is perfect for a romantic date. It's a pretty spacious island. 5TY_Nb_e5criDA0yfhW6TQ.review_text: The Only Floating Island in the World!  Right here in San Francisco, right down at Pier 41, just a stone throw from the sea lions at Pier 39.  What a treat. You find the phone, pick it up, and they send a boat to pick you up and take you to a man-made island for dinner. It turns out your boat pilot is none other than Mr. Forbes himself, who made the island back in the 70's as a private home across the bay, and later turned it into a restaurant and towed it to San Francisco, expanding it and making it even better.  There are dining rooms on the island, as well as a light and boat house, but the real treat is downstairs, where you step into a fantastical setting from a very creative mind. Portholes illuminated to glimpse the fish swimming by, and decor that is surreal, fireplaces, a great long bar, and plenty of 2 and 4 top tables.  The bar is excellent, the martini's dry, the scotch wet. Imbibe and enjoy  and then there's the chow: no so good for vegetarians, but carnivores will delight in the offerings. This is not haute cuisine, 4 stars to be sure, and priced accordingly.  Did I mention that you can see and be seen by sea lions? Wow!  We had a great time, and am so glad that this wonderful little island decided to make San Francisco its home. Enjoy!

t5jtBiNToaDzJcJakgeFNw.review_text: Coolest restaurant *ever*.  This place is so awesome.  Watching fish swim by the portholes while sitting next to the fireplace and enjoying some fine dining on a man made "island" aka huge weird houseboat.  Fabulous.  If I were just rating the food, I'd give it 3.5 or 4 stars.  The sole was nice, but I've had better.  The mushroom ragout wasn't too exciting.  Some of the sides were the best part.  Plus the desert.  Chocolate mouse was amazing.  We also had a very nice bottle of wine.  The whole wine list was marked up the standard 2x over retail at least, but regardless there were some nice bottles on there.  Expensive meal, but so frickin' cool I can't get over it.  Definitely will be back for another special occasion.

WecuAsHBDZGj7Z6_sJcQAw.review_text: It was the third gparent/gchildren nautical adventure: 1. RocketBoat (go right now: yelp.com/biz/rocket-boat…) 2. SF Sailing Company (still a bit queasy: yelp.com/biz/san-francis…) 3. Forbe's Island. I have no idea when this plan was hatched. It was probably right after we got off the RocketBoat (did you hear me? I said go right now!), which was right around my sister's 29th birthday. We docked near this intriguing bit of land mass called Forbes Island, and grandpa suggested we return one year later for my sister's 30th birthday. As you loyal readers already know, when grandpa says jump, I say how high? Done and done. I'll get the picky stuff out of the way. Food was meh. Could have used more seafood in the seafood salad, and the reference to spinach in my otherwise good salmon dish would more accurately be described as a hint of spinach. Mango sorbet was delicious, all very expensive. But you are not just paying for food. You are paying for Forbes himself to shuttle you from dock to island in his boat (not a bad gig), as he answers the same questions for the thousand times in the same jolly manner as the last trip. You are paying to feel the occasional sway of the restaurant as you dine underwater. You are paying to eat on an island in SF proper. As my grandma so eloquently said when audibly yelping the experience: "you get a boat ride." True that grandma. And what you can't put a price tag on, and what will make this meal memorable no matter what, is that around the table were my grandparents, my mother who often has to be dragged kicking and screaming into the city (she'd say the same thing about me to the east bay - love you mom!), my always game stepdad, some of our closest friends and the star of the moment, the best sister anyone could ever ask for. Don't believe me? Do a search of my yelps for "brunch battle". Plus, she posts things on my Facebook wall like "Can't wait to read your Forbes Island yelp and would also like to inform you that my favorite outfit of yours (my 29th bday party) was replaced as of yesterday (my 30th bday dinner)!" A four star dinner/experience in honor of a five star sister.

qethMNVnmuHd1I4on52Hhw.review_text: All in all, an experience NOT TO BE MISSED in San Francisco!!!  A few folks on Yelp who previously reviewed Forbes Island, as you can see here, mentioned that it was uber-touristy. That was not our experience at all, believe it or not. We went on a Saturday night, at around 8 pm, and there was no one "touristy" to speak of in our company. In fact, one of the things I liked MOST about this place was that it was not crowded, rather it was totally relaxed and mellow. There was a total absense of that "get you seated, get you your food, and get you out" vibe that so many restaurants unfortunately send out these days. When I go out to dinner, usually I like to chill out and plan on it taking a few hours. We were definitely able to do this at Forbes Island.  Aside from all that, I really loved a lot of aspects of this place. You really feel like you are on vacation and have been transported to another time and place! It's rad. The food was pretty good, not outstanding, but I didn't mind because I was was so completely wowed by everything else! It IS quite expensive (no entree under $25) but keep in mind that you are probably paying for more than the food...for example, the fact that you are eating dinner on a boat that is designed as an island with a sandy beach and a light house!!! If you are tired of going to the same places for dinner in SF, and want to really mix up you routine, go here! UsYM-IAo6DbHsLXChKZO6A.review_text: Not only a Fantastic meal, but an Adventure! One of the best kept secrets in San Francisco, located at pier 39, but don't let that scare you.  As a San Franciscan you probably do everything possible to avoid pier 39, however, Forbes Island is well worth it.  The restaurant is located on a floating island by the seal lions, but to get there you need to hitch a ride on the Forbes own water taxi.  A small boat picks you, and other dinners up, every 30 minutes near the entrance to pier 39.  A 5 minute boat ride brings you to Forbes Island, less than 100 yards away, but only accessable by boat.  Enjoy a great meal then when you're ready the boat brings you back to the pier entrance.  I've been lucky enough to eat here 4 times, and each time my friends and I have had a great time and fantastic meal.  The help was always attentive without being stuffy.  Check out forbeslsland.com for more information.

m9yv__gCeDomqFdblaDDfA.review_text: Absolutely loved the unique experience and had such a great time, just a couple of hiccups, however:  1) I made a reservation online via their website directly, but never got any confirmation calls.  I had to call the restaurant to confirm and my name was not listed even though I got an e-mail, so their online reservation system is flawed and unreliable. 2) The "Captain" who took us to the restaurant was quite rude.  I stood by the dock and he just flat out told me I shouldn't be standing there.  Later on, he said we should be waiting by the gate and not enter the gate without permission.  Hmmm..... we wouldn't have known.  I wasn't given specific instructions when we made the reservation either, confusing YES.  Other than the two hiccups, it was a wonderful experience.  We took a "water taxi/shuttle" to the island and the boat ride was about three minutes, very cool indeed.  Not sure if I'd recommend ladies to wear high heels to this island.  Read on to find out more.  :P  The food was absolutely delicious.  I had a Clam Chowder, Filet Mignon and tried some of my friend's avocado, crab meat, and baby scallops salad, and the dishes were all divine!!  Our server is a lady who was originally from Ukraine (didn't get her name).  She is personable, friendly, nice, started a conversation with us, and made us feel welcome.    Since Forbes is a floating island and the dining experience is "under the water", make sure to be prepared ahead of time if one is prone to seasickness. After dinner, we took 55 steps to get to the top of the lighthouse and the panoramic view of the city was absolutely gorgeous and impeccable, could get windy though, so make sure to layer up.  Forbes is a secret spot that most people have never heard of, including myself.  My friend heard about it on the radio and that's how we found out the "island" in the first place.  I would highly recommend Forbes Island if someone is looking for a sweet and romantic date night or celebrating a special occasion.  We went there to celebrate a Birthday and all of us had a great time.  I'd very much like to go back next time again.  :D
