4kk0sFVcYDS-GPR9OrWspA.review_text: No one goes to a restaurant around Pier 39 area just to eat.  You're going for some touristy reason;  you want something nutty, something scenic, something San Francisco.  Forbes Island is a great place to meet your "something special"" needs.    You leave the madding Fisherman's Wharf crowd for Forbes Island via a 3-minute, low-key shuttle-boat that putters you away from strollers, dogs, and loud happy people.  When you land, you look back on the Pier 39 craziness, and it looks beautiful from 1/10 of a mile away.  So does the San Francisco shoreline and the Bay.    But, you're here to eat, so you go downstairs, somewhat below the water line, to a warm, wood-toned room for a small menu of well thought-out and competently executed dishes.  It's nice food, above being "okay."  And, the room layout and atmosphere are snug and friendly.  The full, but not lavishly stocked, bar features moderately priced drinks that help you de-stress from the shoreside excitement you've left behind.  Our meal was served by flawlessly friendly, low-key staff.  We were allowed to linger and enjoy the evening. The halibut cheeks were tasty and better than I expected.  I've seen other comments that complained that the food isn't "special". Well, it's better than what we make at home, and, frankly, I was surprised at the quality for a restaurant at this touristy location.  When we left the restaurant we explored the lighthouse and other views as we waited for the boat back to tourist central.  TIP FOR LOCALS:  Forbes Island is NOT impossible to get into, even during high tourist holidays.  We reserved a week ahead for the Saturday evening of Fleet Week when there was an America's Cup Race trials on the Bay.  We boated over to the restaurant with a couple that were "walk ins" who were seated without delay.  Forbes Island is on our list for repeat visits, especially for those days that involve out-of-town guests who think that they have to go to Pier 39's attractions in order to say that they'be seen San Francisco.

XJgRdHOsgypEba4oKwAh1w.review_text: Forbes Island is a terrific, unique experience.  A visit involves a certain amount of kitsch--from being shuttled to the restaurant by pontoon boat (sometimes by Forbes Kiddoo himself) to the thatched huts and tiki torches.  The restaurant is actually a floating island, complete with palms, sand, rocks, a lighthouse, and buildings.  There are a couple dining rooms up on top, but the main dining room is below deck.  It doesn't offer any view, but it's a very cozy experience with Tudor paneling, a fireplace, and portholes through which you might catch the shadow of a fish swimming past.  I can't say enough about the service--extremely warm and friendly! At one point we asked about a local landmark, and our waiter brought another over (who knew the area better) and she spent more than five minutes chatting with us and sharing tips.    The food was excellent.  I had a flat iron steak.  The cut was only okay, but the preparation was excellent.  My wife felt her salmon ranked among the best she's had in her life.  For desert, both the Chocolate Mousse and Berry Napoleon were terrific.  If you go, a certain amount of patience is recommended.  You frequently have to call for the pontoon boat to pick you up, and we waited for about 20 minutes for the boat to return to deliver us back to shore.  We'll definitely visit again!

ir5UE9PlL0_C4Y1hz4auUw.review_text: We just went here for our first year anniversary! Someplace different and very cool! Highly commend experiencing Thai place at least one time! Light house is amazing! A must do! Forbes himself was our captain to and from the island!

E9ZuheZdt5fgq4ItiLHdIg.review_text: Food was incredible, ambiance was unique and cozy, and our waiter was very attentive and professional. Our service was top notch.    Someone suggested this little gem to me and it turned out to be such an enchanting experience.    We both ordered the fillet, which was cooked perfectly; tender and savory.  It came with some type of cheesy broccoli cheese quiche which was INCREDIBLE!    Overall, we had a fantastic night dinning here.  I wish I took pictures, because it was unlike any restaurant I have ever experienced, but unfortunately I did not.  The restaurant is comparable to dinning on a high end pirate ship---almost equivalent to eating in Captain Hook's quarters.   In all my years of visiting SF I never even noticed this place, or rather did not know it was a restaurant, which made it more unique!    As to the person who wrote that the menu was "entirely overwhelming"-- I have no idea where this is coming from, it must be due to them not being able to comprehend the menu items, as the menu is very small.    Additionally, they wrote "weak drink selection", which I respectfully disagree with, as they have a bar filled with anything you want, and top notch high end wine.    Needless to say, this place was better than expected.    LASTLY the bruschetta was AHHHHMAZING.  One of the best bruschetta I have ever had, if not the best.  I would love to be it eating now.     If you are looking for a plushly unique restaurant with highly appetizing food, then I absolutely suggest you come here.

5aCEquYmXUIsWmpUp1gqxA.review_text: Went on a Wednesday Night.   SF Dine About Town Jan 2008.  This place is not about YOU.  It's not about YOU spending money and expecting an experience.  Forbes island is about a man and his dream, his life and his island.  He happens to be willing to share it with you and it really feels like a labor of love.  Don't get me wrong, he's not giving shit away for free, he's out to make money, and gimmicky or not, this is how he chooses to do it.  How many of us really love what we do??  His website is awesome so check it out and pay attention to the directions.  I didn't and walked in a giant circle.  Forbes himself drives the shuttle boat and will give you a brief tour and history of the island.  I suggest you read about it on the website so you don't show up dumb like me.  It really is very fascinating. Next time I go, it needs to be the summer time so I can actually enjoy a sunset and sit outside.  Jeff had the dine about town options - salad, salmon and chocolate mousse.  It was all very yummy. I had the mussels - which were delicious and probably the best I've ever had.  They were tender and juicy and would be the highlight of this place if it weren't for the fact that it's a floating island and all that.  For my meal I had the filet mignon which is what I had the last time I was here (3 years ago) and it's as delicious as I remembered it.  For dessert, I ordered the mixed berries - also delectable.  I was bummed that they were out of the creme brulee and the apple tart desserts, but the 2 we ordered made up for it.    The actual dining area was small but cozy.  Well place mirrors made it appear larger.  Although it's cozy, the size of the tables themselves are generous enough that you don't feel like you're eaves dropping on the breakup conversation happening at the next table. Definitely don't come here with people you can't have a conversation with as service was a tad slow.  It took a while for us to get our menu's and bread, but once our waitress introduced herself to us, she was the model of service and friendliness. The actual pacing of the meal was on the slower side (hence why it's imperative you bring a good conversationalist along).   In summary, I had a very nice meal here which was in addition to the novelty of being on a floating island.  Those ultra sensitive to motion sickness should stay away - it's very slight, but you definitely will feel it rocking.

fC-gLfHWa73dWK6nFYV40w.review_text: I'd have to say this is my favorite "date restaurant" by far. It makes a wonderful surprise (as long as you make sure they don't get seasick beforehand), and the whole process of taking the boat to the island and touring around it is a lot of fun before being seated in the below-decks dining area, which is very romantic.   I've been there several times, and I absolutely love the filet mignon. It his been cooked perfectly every time ordered.   I'll never cease to be baffled by the reviews on this site marking this restaurant down for ridiculous things such as windiness, seasickness, or "touristiness." I've been a bay area resident most of my life, and I didn't find it touristy in the slightest, in fact it seems to be hiding in plain sight as far as I can tell. All the cheesy glitz around the pier hides a great place for yummy food and a lovely, quiet romantic dinner. I even saw one criticizing the place for not having more underwater "windows" otherwise known as portholes. Yeah, there's this thing called structural integrity. I don't want to die, at least before I finish dessert!  As for critics who really harp on the price, yeah it's a bit on the high side if you were to compare it to some place on the street selling the same food. However, if you're frugal to the point where this is a huge issue, (really, it's not) then honestly the thought behind taking your significant other out somewhere special is probably lost on you anyway.  For everyone else, definitely don't miss out on this place, especially if you have someone with sea-legs that you'd like to show a great time.

k0ma9kBYhmyrSusJP9RWNg.review_text: If you're looking to make dinner the main event of the night, come to Forbes Island. It is definitely an experience. If you're coming for great food, skip it.  A couple things to keep in mind before you go: unless you've seen the little Forbes Island boat shuttle thing while strolling the Embarcadero, it's going to be hard to find. My boyfriend and I walked up and down the Pier by 39 a couple times before giving up and calling the restaurant. They said to look for a yellow boat and they're right next to it. Sure enough, there is was. The Forbes Island dock is TINY. Come early to make sure you're not super late like we were. Also, if you're prone to motion sickness, take some meds first. My boyfriend got fairly sick and couldn't wait to get off the island by hour two.   The food was just okay. I think I liked Forbes Island for the experience more than anything. But, if I we spent regular money on it, I'd give it only 2 stars. We were lucky enough to go during Dine About Town.

Q9nsGbHNyukm6V6ohuxlvA.review_text: I based my reasoning to go here off the reviews ... and the fact you take a boat to the island (how cool!).   What i didn't expect was how the restaurant sways ... i mean obviously it would be you're UNDER water!   Our reservations were at 5, we had requested a private area (as it was our wedding anniversary). Normally, when you request a more private seating and inform them its your wedding anniversary, they accommodate.  Instead - we were seated in this teeeeeeny corner, amongst all other patrons :( we might as well sat with them because the tables are so close!   Trying to overcome the seating arrangement, i sit down and look at my wine glass - it wasn't cleaned, there was LIPSTICK marks on it.   Aside from the swaying of the restaurant (which got me woozy), and the dirty glass... the waitress we had was super sweet and they brought us our food relatively quick. I had the salmon and husband has the filet. Dinner was good, dessert YUM, their wine selection could be more extensive.   The light house is nice (ladies, beware and do not wear 6 inch heels).   Overall, ive been to better places and most probably wouldn't be going back here.   cheers!

SLGN2kIDc4SFAxRiNsNuYw.review_text: I had a mission.  To find a restaurant in San Francisco that would knock the socks off my fiancé on his birthday. Birthdays for us are a special celebration - every year I try to top the last and have been successful thus far.  Three things to know about my fiancé.  He loves water, he loves fish and he loves to eat -  voilà!  Forbes Island was the perfect match!  We arrived at Pier 41 just before sunset and made our way to the boat docks where we were immediately welcomed by our Captain.  At this point, the fiancé was quite confused, which I happily reveled in.  It is a short boat ride to Forbes Island - a floating restaurant on a man made island.  Before dinner, we walked up the lighthouse steps and watched the beautiful sunset from the top.  The views are amazing and quite worth the lighthouse hike in 3 inch heels.  The restaurant is actually located underwater and is quite impressive.  The English Tudor decor and lighting all create a romantic ambiance.  We were seated next to a porthole and while toasting to another great year, would occasionally see little fish swim by as my fiancé grinned from ear to ear.  The food is also remarkable.  Classic French fare went very well with the mood of the milieu.  Sea bass and filet were ordered, along with more spirits and birthday dessert.  The highlight of the evening was spending time with the owner of Forbes Island, Forbes Thor Kiddoo.  He has lived quite the impressive and interesting life.  I highly suggest speaking with him as his life stories are fascinating and unique!   The birthday dinner was a success.  It was the perfect evening at the perfect restaurant .. mission accomplished.

gdBJOLrD59aZPYhIcf_BLA.review_text: For our last night of our honeymoon, my husband and I gave Forbes Island a try. The taxi boat driver (and I'm assuming the owner?) was very friendly to us. I've never been on any kind of boat before, and he made sure I was comfortable getting on and off the boat. He escorted us down to the dining area and we were seated immediately. Our wait staff was friendly and on top of everything. The island itself is adorable. There is seating upstairs of the boat to hang out and as soon as we were waiting to be picked up at the dock the taxi boat came back in no time.   The food was great - we had a mushroom sort of appetizer that was delicious. I had filet mignon which was cooked just right. My husband had some sort of fish and I remember it being quite good. It was all very romantic and although it was pricey, I believe it was worth it.   As others have said, if you are prone to get seasick or not used to being on water, it may not be a good idea. I didn't get sea sick, but the rocking of the island was something to get use to. Overall it was a very fun experience. I'd probably come here again.

-0EVgSWMMj5yhuhcIhjMuQ.review_text: Good experience. Unique how we had to take the boat for us to get in the restraunt. I loved the looks and the light house. Not enough options to choose from what to eat. I believe there was only like 5 different kind of dish? the waitress did not had the best service. It was not worth what we paid for. The portion was very little and the food was not VERY tasty. it was OKAY. i thought it was a good one time experience but I wouldn't go there again for like a place to hang out with friends.

h0KYrTpYYb7_abSd1mGQpA.review_text: Both my husband and I had our wedding reception dinner here.  We couldn't have been happier with the location and food.  All of our guests had a great time and were amazed by the food  and atmosphere.  We can't wait to go back !!!!

g1VP1z9ASviXjOfyv2-ZVA.review_text: I love this restaurant!  This is another one of those places that I like so much that I want to tell the naysayers that if you don't like this place, you don't deserve this place.  Unbelievably beautiful spot, and despite being an "island" built onto a boat in the touristy ground-zero of San Francisco, it somehow resists being kitchy and is, dare I say it, downright tasteful. I have no idea how they pulled that one off. If they'd have gone the kitchy route Forbes Island would, for better or worse, be a San Francisco landmark on par with the Tonga Room, but somehow the builder's resisted and kept it beautiful, but still plenty fun.  Great food, great cocktails, a memorable experience. If I had to offer some constructive criticism I'd say the bread could use improvement, but hey I'm a bread snob. And I personally thank them for not serving the damn sourdough that all the other San Francisco restaurants feel obliged to serve.

UvRUygcyvpJuHh1BiZrrbQ.review_text: Best idea, concept in a restaurant. This place is on a island in between Pier 39 and Pier 41. You have to take a small little boat on the water to get to it.  Now DISMALER if you are a person that gets sea sick at all do not come here. I don't get sea sick but I was a little light headed the first 20 minutes there. After we start eating and drinking it got better.  The food is incredible! I got the risotto even though my boyfriend's dinner the Denver steak was a better choice.   Mine as mushrooms in it and some chopped veggies. His steak had this amazing dijon sauce and scalloped potatoes!!!! Oh and string beans! All my favs.  Our waiter was really good. I can't remember I time in the past 3 years where I complimented the wait staff but I really like this gentlemen. He spoke slightly soft which intrigued me.   You can go up to the lighthouse and look out, it was raining when we were there but we still went up.  COOL place more people need to go.

pFbtLhyMFYsPk6zP7mMRDw.review_text: Great views,Fun place,Little over priced but the location makes up for it.Boat is never on time.Wharf parking prices are insane.Great place to take people from out of town.BTW some people get sea sick if it is windy,the island moves like a rocking boat

lmNGSh_nFat7tT36RRd0Lw.review_text: This place was amazing !!  I saw this place  on a television show and had to check it out. uTDxT-lAVI31gBg9Fgz8hQ.review_text: "Fantasy Fine Dining Aboard The World's Only Floating Island"  If that line (pulled directly from the website) doesn't convince you to visit, then I don't know what will.   Curious? You should be. Confused? Yeah, that too. I've been twice and I still don't fully understand what's going on here.  Forbes is a wacky old man who captains the boat to the island. I'm pretty sure he has a glass eyeball. Was it lost in a fight with a nearby sea lion? I'd like to think so.

qltDwzQRSu8FnEFFJg5HaA.review_text: A group of 6 of us went the other night.  Loved the salty old dog with the great sense of humor who picks you up at the pier in his boat and takes you to "the island" This is where the magic is...  An amazing view of the city, and embarcadero to Russian Hill. Truely one of the best views there is...with the chill in the air and the barking sea lions. Just a treat. The lighthouse is fun as well.  The food...Well just captivating and very delicious.  I had the wild mushroom ragout with goat cheese on crostini as an appetizer...OMG so good. Wasn't too hungry so went with the dungenous crab/avocado and heirloom tomato salad and the clear broth seafood chowder.  The salad was simple, crisp, cold and delcious. The non-cream seafood chowder was really one of the best i've ever had.  packed with shrimp, scallops, mussels, salmon and spiced so that my tastebuds screamed in delight.  Couldn't have enjoyed it more.  The waiter who is a cross between bradley cooper and a young richard gere, is super friendly, knows his menu, and wine list and is pretty easy on the eyes as well...:-)  So we will definately be back. A really wonderful night in a gem of a hideway off Pier 39... The history behind this place is pretty cool too. Do a google search ..  Update. Forbes Islands hosted our workplace Holiday party and did an amazing job. I think we are going to try to use them again this next year.  .

qxX02LikmZaD9IrMq0Mowg.review_text: Spectacular-spectacular-spectacular...short ferry ride to the island, romantic ambiance, delicious food and gorgeous view from the light tower (if it's not foggy...you know SF).  Forbes Island is truly a special place. H8q4N1DNgogAxo3T22x1bw.review_text: Me and my friends went there on 4/12...we had a 7:30pm reseravtion but we are not able to get into the shuttle boat until 8:00pm because they had a big party before our reservation time and some people there were running late, so they need to seat them first... pJ1SKD4XZr-6p9FnG8yZ2w.review_text: If you get motion sickness, pop a Dramamine pill before dining at this place.  This is pretty much a floating restaurant. To get to the "island", you'll need to take a 2-3 minute shuttle boat ride. When you arrive on the island, you can go up to the lighthouse and take some photos. You'll get a great view if you go up the stairs in the lighthouse.  Since I experienced motion sickness, I didn't eat much of my food. From my tasting, I wasn't too impressed, but I'm sure there are other dishes that are better. I came here for an event with about 40+ people and the majority of us felt sick. I'm usually pretty good on boats and don't get motion sickness, but this floating restaurant was something else.   I'll never forget how I felt when I was on the boat leaving the island. It was a nice feeling to be back on land. After this horrific experience, I don't think I'll ever go back here again.  Just in case you didn't take some Dramamine, you can visit the bartender and ask him/her for some ginger pills.

7_vWkFSeVR3M6HvV0XMg3w.review_text: What an absolutely wonderful dining experience.... like being in the captain's quarters on a ship!    Beautiful interior, with intimate dining and great lighting.  Outside, you can sip your wine on the deck, or climb the lighthouse steps for an absolutely fantastic view of SF!   We were so fortunate to have Casey as our waiter, who suggested marvelous starters, entrees, and desserts!   (Hint: try the flatiron steak...the potatoes it comes with are heavenly!)  Casey  was so great, so personable and knowledgeable, to every single table!    A wonderful place for a special birthday, or romantic evening!

vDN-WtiffhQL6fbLyqrumg.review_text: It has been a decade since I have been to Forbes Island. At the time, the head chef was from The Sonoma Inn, that translates to one of the best meals of my life!!!  This place is fantastic, in the sense of living like James Bond, eating dinner under water with the portholes looking out in to the ocean, a few fish will swing by to say hello.   The best room in the place was a small room off the back that had seated 4 near  the Captains Chambers, it really felt magical and special. We had dressed up all Victorian fancy and a friend spied a foot pump organ and she began to play a beautiful song. Food is excellent, the wine is yummy, and the ambiance is fantastic!   Forbes is a living legend if only half of us could manifest our dreams such as he...   GO here, go here, go here! Yes, you can spend just as much on a meal anywhere in the city but this place is cool.

k4tPYRuN_DExu4qvMunj-w.review_text: History lesson.  When moored off of the Sausalito city front, they shot pornography on the barge now known as Forbes Island.

6oKH_D7_RLPnrhRvxFd9wQ.review_text: As touristy as this spot gets, it's perfect if you get there right when they're open a 5PM It's quiet, dim and romantic. I brought my date here as a surprise. We've both never been so it was a new experience...dining underwater?? I wouldn't know where else to do such a thing.   There are a few portholes here and there under the "island" but the water is so dirty you can't really see much. I sure didn't see any fish through all that green water.  The decor and the ambiance was really nice, there's a rose at every table and even a nice gas powered lantern. Our nice waitress sat us next to the fireplace, which my date and I were quite fond of.   The food and service were excellent, from the salad all the way to the dessert. Time flies when you're having a good time, as we found ourselves still at the restaurant 4 hours later.  After dinner we went to explore the island and the lighthouse, the lighthouse quite honestly was the best part about this place, great view! It's not too high up but it really is quite nice.  Overall, the both of us loved this place. If you want a quiet romantic mood, definitely be there when they open, by the time we left they were quite busy and the noise level was almost sky high. If you don't mind that. Definitely try this place out anytime. I'm just waiting for an excuse to go back already!

TCSyul4Oj5IFvW-_Omeewg.review_text: Was looking for a special place to celebrate a big anniversary - and stumbled across a review of this place.  Funny thing - I've seen Forbes MANY times over the years of taking family to Fisherman's Wharf - but a complete lack of curiosity had me ignoring it until said review.  Decided this HAD to be the place, and made the reservation on our anniversary - a Saturday in early July (note that....).  We arrived at the Wharf, and proceeded to spend almost an hour attempting to park - remember that Saturday in July?  AND a nice day?  Dumb dumb dumb.  We finally did park though, and after playing tourist, I guided the wife over to the docks, where we almost immediately caught the boat to take us to the Island.  We arrived, and made a beeline for the lighthouse.  VERY cool pics were taken.  Definitely an awesome idea!  We explored the island a bit, and finally went past the waterfall to go downstairs, where we were quickly seated.  We ordered some wine and perused the menu.  Quick note - I saw MASSIVE comments/complaints in Yelp reviews about salt permeating everything.  Well, I beg to differ.  What it DOES permeate, admittedly, is the butter.  Hand made using sea salt - definitely an interesting (but not bad) taste on the (of course) sourdough bread.  Neither of us tasted any other heavy salt use.  The wife ordered short ribs, I ordered sole - along with the avocado bruschetta for the wife and a salad for moi.  The appetizers were served quickly and were quite good.  The meals followed, and while the sole was a bit bland, the short ribs were perfect.  Overall, AWESOME place, with tons of atmosphere.  In fact, the only real ding I can give this place is that the primary dining area is just frigging warm.  It was well above 80...simply too warm.  One other quick side note - I saw a couple of complaints about seasickness.  Yes, you're on a boat (or a floating island...whichever).  But it's a frigging BIG boat. In a harbor.  With about the only real water movement being the change in tidal flow every four hours...and that's pretty minor.  I seriously don't think you're going to find this to be an issue (if you do, you probably should not be anywhere near water...move to Kansas.  Really).   ;-)

k0or6C41LFgvFV1SvfEouw.review_text: If i could give it no stars i would. My boyfriend planned for us go here on our 1 year anniversary and it turned out to be a very negative experience. I enjoyed the boat ride over to the restaurant which left me with high expectations. But my high expectations were quickly shot down once we got to the ''island''. The windows, which were supposed to give us a clear view of the ocean, were so dirty you couldn't see anything. The restaurant was tacky and had no atmosphere. But this would have been ok if the food was good and our waitress wasn't extremely rude! We did not get what we ordered and she refused to fix it so we had to eat undercooked meat. The food was way overpriced for the way the way it tasted. On top of the bad food  the waitress had offered us many "refills" of soda but she failed to tell us we were being charged for each refill. At the end we ended up paying a whopping $20 just on soda. For that price the money could have gone towards a bottle of wine. Also if you get motion sick I do not recommend this place because it rocks back and forth. To be honest it was completely overrated. I am very disappointed and sad that my boyfriends plans for an amazing date were ruined.

ZyfsHU3TLnhH6oMpT-yqxA.review_text: Came for the DAT menu and the experience....it was amazing!  Mr.Forbes picked us up on the shuttle boat ..told us about how he built the island in Sausilito & reminded us to visit the lighthouse. He also pointed out the best places for pictures after dinner.  The ambiance was nice, server was friendly.  Food was very good with large portions (so large that we each took 1/2 of our plates home) - pan seared flat iron steak, salmon w/pesto rice, berry napolean & chocolate mousse - we thoroughly enjoyed our meal.  It was pretty windy last night, so toward the end of our meal, I was starting to feel seasick from the swaying of the island. RKfETgoe0wuZds8EMDBw0Q.review_text: Had a great time here.  The short boat ride is kinda ridiculous because it is sooo shortbut also really adds to the experience.  You can walk around the floating island and enjoy the view of the sea lions resting on the adjacent floats.  Take a hike up to the lighthouse and catch the nice sunset.  Then you go down into the bowels of the island which is really a nice dark salon.  Kinda like being below deck of an old pirate ship.  You can let your imagination go wild because there are no windows.  Only a fireplace, bar, lots of mirrors.  The service was excellent.  Food was delicious.  Nice wine selection.  I enjoyed the slow rocking sensation.  So if you are prone to getting sea sick, this might not be the place for you.  If you're like me and enjoy the rocking and good food, go ahead and give this place a try.

OSJhKYZeTZZvRfO8e0gwJw.review_text: Everything from the pontoon boat driver/bartender to our food to our drinks was great! It is a must for a visitor to San Fran - get a reservation at least week or two before though! It is a unique, fun dining experience that you will really enjoy!   Make sure you go to the top of the lighthouse - if you time it right, you can get an amazing sunset view!   The well prepared food, the funny and engaging staff, the cozy atmosphere of dining underwater and bathroom that you could only get to by going through a bedroom, make this a really fun, exciting dining experience. It was our favorite meal of our whole trip!

7yrYQZVt-kzAFNO_5wq3sA.review_text: What a great night!!!  My friend and I waivered a bit about the prices, but we decided it was worth the "experience".  It WAS!!    The reservation was easy to book, we lucked out and took someone else's cancellation.  We met on the pier where the salty captain ferried us across the pier to the "island".  We were sharing the island with a private party having a Pirate-themed birthday, which was a riot.    We were seated right in the center of the dining area next to the fireplace, which was PERFECT!  We had delicious cocktails and top-quality steaks.  My friend had the Filet Mignon and I had the Flat Iron Steak, which was to die for.  It was the best steak I've had in a long time.  I also had the clam chowder, which was seasoned perfectly and just the right texture.  For dessert, we shared the butterscotch pudding and literally licked our bowl clean.    After we ate, we climbed to the top of the lighthouse and enjoyed the glassed-in view while we watched the harbor winds rip through the palm trees just outside the windows.  The service was wonderful and it was a really incredible evening for both of us!!  Worth the price, and you really have to go there to fully understand the experience.    Ask the captain about the history of the island, he'll tell you some great stories!!

Cry5ZB6de1Yl9iP3AOfneA.review_text: We brougt our mom here for her 50th bday, and high expectation that, unfortunately, were not met. Not even close.  When we made our way into the "underwater" dining room, we stood around, literally, for at least 10 minutes. Waiters and waitresses kept rushing past us (although there were only two other parties seated), pushing and excusing themselves by. There was no place to check in, and when we finally hailed one of the servers, she told us to "wait". We found ourselves a table that was able to accomodate the seven of us, so we sat ourselves. The bartender refused to let us order our drinks at the bar , and our waitress was THE most rude server Ive ever had. Two of our orders came out wrong, and one meal was even forgotten all-together. To top it off, the two mini port holes with views of the water were completely corroded, so we might as well have had dinner at a regular restaurant. Miserable experience all around, but mostly due to the staff.

MuBI8loK61lNv_aAp-Iz2g.review_text: soooo far..... my favorite Dine About Town meal!  Decided to plan a Girl's Night Out at this very interesting dining experience. Had some trouble finding the dock, but when we got there.. our captain and boat was readily awaiting us! Some jokes and two short minutes later, we arrived at Forbes Island.  Went downstairs to the restaurant slightly below sea level and was greeted by the host with the French accent. I told him I had reservations for 7-- but he couldn't find me booked in anywhere! Errr... what?!!  "No worries", he said, "Why don't you ladies go check out the lighthouse first, and when you come back we'll have a table upstairs set up for you." Ahh thank you sweet Frenchman!  We climbed up the spiraling stairway of the lighthouse dangerously in our heels to overlook the wharf and sea lions. Funniest quote of the night... a lady pushed us aside and asked "are those whales?" LoL.   And as promised-- our table was ready in their upstairs dining room overlooking the ocean. AHH how romantic... we felt we were sailing on a cruise ship/boat or something too. We would have enjoyed the meal more if we didn't feel the swaying motion. But after awhile, you either get use to it and feel it less or just get sick. *NOTE: request to be seated upstairs... downstairs is just wayy too dark and stuffy.  We all either had the salad or soup (which was roasted red pepper for the day), salmon or steak as our entree, and chocolate mousse cake or berry compote as our dessert choice. Nothing innovative or creative about the menu options --  just plain good old American faire! (aka hearty portions, clean, straight forward ingredients).   Not the most memorable meal, but definitely not a forgettable one (if that makes sense). Service was excellent all around. Our waitress was sweet as my chocolate mousse cake.   Will I come back again?   You bet I will for Dine About Town. In my book, its one of the better Dine About Town deals!   And seriously.. how many places do you know that require you to take a boat to a restaurant and lighthouse on a man-made island?

y3HFVx8nbNmomSc-PWOy-g.review_text: So sad...  After dining there on three occasions (not by my choice), it was everything I expected...a tourist trap.  If this restaurant did not have a gimmick and was not located at Pier 39, there is no way it could survive.  However, thanks to the tourist trade, there is always a fresh influx of innocent, unsuspecting victims who are hooked by the concept of a restaurant floating and tied up at the end of the pier.  Once you are seated and the novelty wears off, the food starts to appear and reality sets in.  From a culinary standpoint, the food was a major disappointment.  The lamb was overcooked and mealy and overall, the entire experience was like a bad continental dining nightmare from the 70s.  Even with diminished expectations, each time we dined there, we just could not believe how bad the food was.      In a culinary town like San Francisco, known for its dining, Forbes Kiddoo should be made to walk the plank for this culinary disaster, this homage to gastronomic embarassment.  Even better, he should be forced to dine in his own restaurant.    Thank gawd Yelp gives diners a way to see what others think before trying out a new place.  I only wish is that Yelp would allow me to give a rating less than one star, how about half a star?  Now that would be appropriate.  Concept: 3 stars, Food: 1/2 star  Check the other people's reviews written about this place and lend credence to the negative ones for those are the ones telling you the truth.  I can't believe this place still exists.  There oughta be a law.

GWilkDW_fcxKygfvsssKEQ.review_text: Pierre is the man! All servers I've encountered there are excellent. delicious food, ambience, everything. and when you see a little fish swim by the porthole, that's just a plus!

tfTw2QKOa053xcPvCcE6mQ.review_text: I am in love with this place and hope to have my wedding reception here someday.  It is so charming and so hidden.  I have been here on numerous occasions whether for Valentine's day, New Years, birthdays, or just for fun.  The food is always awesome and feeling the gentle rock of the ocean brings me great delight.    I appreciate the awesomeness that is forbes Island and like that even though it is located at the wharf, it is not chintzy or touristy.  I highly recommnd this place to anyone and everyone who wants to experience a hidden gem in San Francisco

o9Oh-hqAvwbGckXKD0zeeA.review_text: 1. Don't go here if you get seasick - you are on a boat basically (same goes for stormy weather) 2. Go early, 5pm, if you want a quiet, romantic dinner 3. Don't be cheap - it's not pricey compared to a decent meal in NYC, and you get the boat ride & view. So have wine & appetizer. 4. Food was very good, not orgasmic but very yummy. 5. Take the limo to the Pier - hey it only adds to the evening!  It was a beautiful January night, clear & not too cold, beautiful views of everything in the bay, and nice service, Forbes aka Captn Scruffy was very nice, took pictures with everyone, we toured all over the "island", nice music, overall a great special-occasion experience. WzgTJg1cWYsFMCZKLHd8-w.review_text: I'm eating on a moving island...   First of all, the waters were so choppy on Saturday night, I literally wanted to vomit. I know, words you do not want to read when researching a place for a potential DINING experience.   The boat was super cute and the sailor (is that the right terminology??) was super super nice!  The island, very pirate-ish. Yes. I took pictures.   The food, was absolutely not impressive by any means.  We didn't get offered the regular menu, like all of the other people did in the restaurant. I ordered a pinot noir and got a glass of white instead - did you think I was color blind?! Victoria C. ordered a Coke and got Pepsi, without a forewarning... so the night was off to a bad start.   Our salads came. To our surprise, it was decent, pleasant. We liked the salads.  Then our main course came. What a waste of potential good food. Victoria C's chicken was dry. That is unacceptable.  Both Leona Z. and my steak ... well, let's just say there was no consistency whatsoever.  We both ordered it medium, mine was mooing and hers was just a little too overdone. It was chewy - gross, and almost the worst steak I've ever had at a fairly nice restaurant.  Dessert impressive.   So food wise, with ambiance, maybe 3 stars. But because our waiter was such a jerk and didn't give a rat's @$$ about service, this review gets down graded to 2 stars.   Lesson: If you want a romantic date, or just experience eating dinner under water - this is the place to go. The ambiance of the whole night was worth the experience, just once.

9SqfKANLVxLp1PfRhYz2tw.review_text: Me and my family have been trying to go to Forbes Island for a long time. But something always came up. Sick kid, knee surgery,and so on. We finally made it for a big birthday. It was a bit confusing trying to find the boat that you take to get there but it all worked out. When we got there we checked out the whole man made island. Very cool.   We were seated at a table with a port hole window with fish swimming by. Lots of fun cocktails. I had the dark stormy say no more. The server was very nice and new the menu like the back of his hand. Was also very good with all of our special dietary needs. All in all the food and service were beyond my expectations. Loved it will go back again.

msHUlHTw9NlsYgwDm1k8sA.review_text: Definitely a unique dining experience, but be warned those that suffer from motion-sickness or get seasick this is definitely NOT the place for you.   We started the evening by waiting alongside pier39 to get picked up by their boat in order to get to their "island". Note: this is not a real island...more like a huge floating mass that appears to look like an island.   After a short 5min ride, we docked onto Forbes island. We were directed to the seating area but also welcomed to explore their lighthouse and outdoor space.   The lighthouse was cool having a wonderful view of the bay, sf skyline, and surrounding pier. This was the highlight of the night.  The restaurant was in the lower level underwater. The sea/nautical theme was very prevalent in this area, looked kinda dated and dirty.  The dining experience was ok, not really tasty just filling. Also, since the island was moving and you're seated underground, for me it made me a bit nauseated and have not that much of an appetite.  In conclusion, good place for a cocktail, view, and interesting new kind of ambience----not that great for dining (especially if you're motion sensitive).

JKRMUCQCcyh5dVgaiuKesw.review_text: I took my mother to dinner at the Island a few years ago and fell in love with the restaurant. I knew I wanted to come back here but for a special private event. I decided to celebrate my 30th birthday in the Sea Lion room. It was one of the most memorable nights of my life. The food, excellent, especially the chocolate mouse with hazelnut crust (to die for), the ambiance perfect and the service 5 star (Tricia). Casey, the event coordinator, went out of his way to make sure everything was perfect.   I highly recommend experiencing dinner at here and especially recommend you celebrating a special event here. It is guaranteed to be a fun night for you and your guests.

mw5I771H5tIbh5o5BhR2PA.review_text: So one of my friends was getting married, and I wanted to throw her a little bridal shower. Her one request was that we go somewhere "festive, unusual, and not too tacky." Forbes Island -- despite basically being a big barge with palm trees and a lighthouse -- somehow pulled off all three.  The high points: the tiki boat, the perfectly roasted chicken, the unbelievably good desserts, and the fact that we could hear the sea lions on Pier 39 while we ate. Oh, and Forbes Kiddoo himself gave us a tour.   The not-so-high points: the price point (I guess it covers the gas for the tiki boat) and the faint swaying that made one of my companions a little green around the gills.  I give it 3.5 slightly waterlogged stars, with a special nod to the ginger creme brulee, which on dry land would have qualified for 5 stars all on its own. Anchors aweigh!

K0C4VkxAUIIXBkGq5kMr8w.review_text: Took my girlfriend here for out first Valentine's Day, and upon sitting down she said, "You really outdid yourself." The food is alright, the wait staff is friendly, and the decor and ambiance is romantic and relaxing. This is a great spot to take that special girl for a special occasion.

8aVYFJHOnYEF9M4onYkhCA.review_text: Took the fella there last night for his Bday dinner and had a totally wonderful experience. We showed up right as the captain pulled up to the dock to ferry us and another couple over to the island. At this point my darling man had no idea what was up because for the first time in my life I managed to keep a surprise a surprise. He was thrilled.  Our first impression of the island was how frickin cool is this! It was a lasting first impression. Our mantra over the course of the evening was "how cool is this". Completely done up in tiki stylie with live palms and plants!  We were promptly offered a table downstairs (which looked cool w/ the murky light coming through the portholes) but chose to sit up stairs. Seriously the best view: Bay Bridge, city sky line and lights reflecting on the water. Loved loved loved the view.  We did the DAT menu with a salad, flat iron steak and berry dessert. All fantastic. The salad was fresh and light. We ordered our steaks medium rare and they came out medium rare! Love that. I know it sounds cheesy that we ordered the same thing but please allow me to justify. He always gets the steak option and I usually get the fish/chicken/whatever else. Then I get serious steak envy. So this time I threw caution into the wind and got the steak; am very pleased w/ my choice. I did add some salt to my meal but I prefer to be in control of salt content anyways so it was all good. The berry dessert was absolutely wonderful. A standout for sure. The berries and sauce were not too sweet and definitely had some tart while the cream was a perfect complement. At a lot of joints the dessert is sort of an afterthought and doesn't compliment or live up to the rest of the meal. This dessert was a star. Disclaimer: I am not a sweets person so it is really out of the norm for me to rave about sweets. This was that good. Our meal was well paced and served by Laurie. She was a really wonderful server. Attentive but not over bearing, she made sure we were comfortable and happy during our meal.  After dinner we wandered around the island and climbed the light house. It is really quite nice to have such a funky, unique spot here in the city. I am already thinking about how I can get back out there. BTW, I laughed all at all the captains jokes. There is just something extra hilarious about nautical humor. Remember, don't miss the boat!

FRLHsMaXlVg9C4G4tO7GpQ.review_text: I really want to give 5 start because atmosphere, service, food and dessert was great and the whole experience of water taxi and island was so unique but unfortunately part of my food (fish) was too salty that my husband shared his food with me and I had mashed potato and vegetable!

yjKyKOVaOZLx5GHIWCo9_A.review_text: Love this place. Had a very romantic dinner with my wife there a couple of months ago. Great food, and charming ambience. Liked it so much we had our department holiday party here. This is by far the best venue we have had for this. Great staff, and the "island" has such great history and uniqueness. Loved it. Deducting a star only because of the price. For a dinner, it is a bit overpriced. For the party, they still charged $6 tap beers,  and $20 corkage. Passed appetizers were ok.

QFaFctgUzblgs1ilW2tp1g.review_text: I had an amazing night here with my girlfriend for my birthday.  It was a pretty cool experience as they shuttle you on a ferry from the wharf to the actual restaurant.  The owner actually lived on the island for a couple of decades and he is the captain of said shuttle.  Food was great, especially for the price paid and the staff was very friendly and attentive.  The only negative thing I could see about it was that there was a fly near our table, but I guess when you're on the Pier or in the water it comes with the territory.  Definitely would go back again!

OSOlzXKZoUzNsIxrBECUSQ.review_text: What a unique experience. A perfect date night. I highly recommend trying Forbes Island to everyone at least once (unless you get sea sick). It's expensive, and the food is not as tasty as it should be for the price, but so worth it anyway! It's such a change of pace.   Captain Forbes Kiddoo picks you up at Pier 39's "I" dock. You can call ahead to make sure he knows your arrival time. I surprised my girlfriend who had no idea what was going on, or who I had called, until he pulled up at the dock. The boat ride over with the Cappy was easily the best part. He's like a professional comedian. He says he lived on the boat/island for 16 years in Sausalito with "Nothing between me and the sand except a skinny native girl." What a great business owner, great story, awesome night, and fantastically unique idea.  The food is pricey, and although plated beautifully it isn't amazing, but the boat is. It's just so much fun you really don't care about the price. I definitely recommend the Avocado Bruschetta. Our waitress was courteous, knowledgeable, and sweet. The expo and bartender too. What a great staff!  I can't believe more people don't know about this place, and it really feels like a well kept secret. It's a great ace in your back pocket when you want to impress. It would also make a great private venue.   I don't know if it was just that it was really really windy out when we went but the boat rocks slightly and the dining area is down below, so if you're prone to sea sickness you need to skip this adventure. I'm sure I'll be back one day. I'd like to go out just to drink at the bar!

h05W4Bse3RYriZTlkwcjBA.review_text: Solid dinner experience in San Francisco.  I really enjoyed this place- the lighthouse is neat, the grounds are nice, the ride there on the private boat was enjoyable.   The food was great, staff friendly, and we sat on the bottom floor beneath sea level- the place shakes from time to time.   Salmon was awesome and they had free post cards they will send our for you. The wine as good.

vXrUBAIN4aoCt7F5p0kU_g.review_text: Wow is how I can describe Forbes Island.  The owner Forbes Kiddo drives you in a boat to his private island.  I didn't know this until after our ride was over, my friend told us during dinner.  The dinning room is so warm and rocks to the ocean waves, very fun, especially with some wine in  your system.  The island is yours to adventure around.  A lighthouse with breathtaking views, interesting areas to take pictures.  My favorite part was the bathroom.  It was so out of the norm.  Girls check it out if you go.  I recommend Forbes for dates or group adventures.

L0llF8KpCg5vdEZIXkbO8w.review_text: I will knock a star off for the dining area being under the water line with no horizon...which made me find out the hard way that I am prone to some seasickness, but not enough hose my evening or kill my apetite.  My department had their Holiday Party here and had a blast - that atmosphere and staff were all amazing. We rented out the whole island for the evening. Casey was great from start to finish with our needs and accommodations (though we didn't have many). The waiters were attentive and kept our glasses full. I didn't drink very much because the motion made me a little nervous about  seasickness so I can't say much about the quaility of their alcoholic drinks (only had a glass of champagne).  Food was good, I had the lamb which I really liked but wasn't too keen on the bean starch thing that came with it. For desert, I had the chocolate mousse which was terrific. When we selected the menu options for the night, it was going to be an either/or for dessert. Sorbet, the mousse and another dessert. Casey had no problem switching us to two options. Good thing too as a lot of people chose the sorbet over the mousse and loved it.  I'm reading the other reviews and sort of jealous people had their weddings here. I'm getting married in the Spring and had no idea this place existed when I made my initial plans. This would have been awesome - but my fiance and I did just have an anniversary so I may drag him here for that :)

KDewJBJknfWvQyHHFNbfdg.review_text: Every man is an island. Every man is an opportunity. An ecosystem. A bar under water. A self-sustained habitat for others to gather, to revel, to encourage, to sway from side to side without anything underneath your feet. No one ever said that man is stable. We're an island with an engine to float where we may, to put the women's bathroom in our master bedroom, to have the most eloquent, fascinating, loving bartender named Pierre put cocktails in front of you. We'll drive you on our boat to our own island. We'll invite such debauchery to go down that the scars compared in Jaws don't compare to the staples in your back scars that could happen at Forbes Island bar. A staple of tourism. A staple of San Francisco. A staple by Vivek S (attempted to pierce skin, but failed because I am a man). More though... a staple of one man wanting he wants -- himself, an island. If there's one place to have one drink in San Francisco, it's a Hendrick's Martini made by Pierre at this bar. By the end of the drink, you'll order another. The island's engine turns on. You float away from what you know. Your own moveable feast. You have what you need -- a martini -- and you have what you are -- an island.

XACJepnddLx_2fuaRKbsSQ.review_text: I adore this place.  My husband & I went here for a special celebration after finding out that a possible cancer scare was just that, a scare.  Anyway, we spent a lot of time getting to know Forbes Kiddo while sipping on martinis at the bar.  I had known of him and met him once long ago when his Island was in Sausalito.  We had a fabulous dinner (the wild mushroom ragout was to die for).    Always the first to arrive and the last to leave, we didn't break from tradition.  We ended up partying on the Island until the wee hours of the morning (5:00 am).  We had the time of our lives.  It was an adventure I will never forget!  I recommend this place to anyone.  It is very unique.  Thank you Forbes and all your staff!

lSFVlEDd8g8z8W-STbLy1w.review_text: I took my girlfriend here for valentines day dinner, and what a mistake that was. The price was out of control for what we got. The crab bisque was actually fantastic. I ordered scallops for my appetizer and got 1 scallop and a shit load of fennel around it. The steak was good but was the size of a plum. Overall the food was good but the amount wouldnt fill up a bird.

8Ces6YdT6j7BYycnZLrSng.review_text: * Update: Forbes Island restaurant has announced that they'll reopen this Friday May 17, 2013. Since the main dining room and kitchen below are intact, they can resume operations a week after the fire. I'm sure that they need the revenue to cover the repair costs. The damaged upstairs dining room will eventually be replaced in the future. And who knows, perhaps even improved by some remodeling.  ********** Just a PSA in case any readers have plans to dine here, that this floating restaurant is temporarily closed due to a fire on May 10, 2013.  Last night or early morning (before 5am), an accidental fire (possibly a table candle overturned) incinerated the dining room above deck. No one was injured. The rest of the island-boat seems intact.  The owner started developing the concept in 1975, and construction was completed in 1980. It was his floating home in Sausalito, for the first twenty something years, and then repurposed into a restaurant more than a decade ago. No idea how long it'll take to rebuild.  Not a good dining choice for anyone who gets seasick, otherwise the novelty can be a memorable and romantic experience. I attended a family affair a long time ago, I don't remember what I had for dinner. The dining rooms above deck are small, but u get great views of the bay. Below deck, the main dining room features vintage nautical decor and a central fireplace, but the room is dim. It's a place u come for special occasions, so menu prices are not cheap. Current entree prices are around +$30 each. And the 4-course Valentine's day special prix fixe is $85.

SYOtU_VChU6NCl0At5PEKA.review_text: March 31st...It is my 55th birthday, so I wanted to do something a little different. I heard about Forbes Island from KOIT radio station, looked it up online and thought it sounded unique. I read alot of the reviews here on Yelp, expected to find a "different" type of restaurant with just O.K. food. I was happy to find a beautiful setting with unique decor, service was great (our servers name was Tricia), the food was delicious.  We had a party of four, reservations were at 6 pm, and we ordered from a special menu called the KOIT Passport. It was a special they were running for the month of March. This included a 3 course meal: 1st course, your choice of soup or salad, all 4 of us had the salad...wonderful taste, nice mix of greens and beautiful presentation. 2nd course, entree, 2 had the Salmon on a bed of rice, covering spinach, they said it was great. My husband and I had the Pan seared Flat Steak with a sauce, and served  with au gratin potatoes and veggies. Very flavorful, cooked perfectly, the potatoes--to die for! Excellent!!!! 3rd course, dessert, all of us had the Chocolate Mousse and none were disappointed...YUMMY!!!!!!!!!!! In addition to the 3 course meal, we also had 3 courses of wines paired with the food....again, perfect!!!! I would certainly recommend this restaurant to anyone and will most definately go again!!!! My only disappointment...it was raining and I would love to have seen the sun setting. Be sure to make the climb to the top of the lighthouse, what a fabulous view!!!! If you get motion sickness, I would recomment taking something, you are on a boat and there is rocking.

iEeb_5RSBLYuoNQm5nlCgA.review_text: The stars are definitely for the experience.  Yes, there is a little phone for the boat.  Yes, there is a boat piloted by a slightly grizzled captain who has an unidentifiable accent that might be a bit of a put on. Yes, the island is really cool (it's actually a huge converted house boat).  The service was very attentive, the locale is wonderful and the dining area is spacious.  It takes a while to get used to the sometimes less than gentle rocking (not scary rocking, just noticable).  The food was servicable, not amazing.  We had a great time and the food was good, but not anything out of character for Pier 39.  However, we will definitely be back with out of town guests becauase it was such a cool, fun experience.  And our waiter was top notch.

4Z-h5qycjy6yY_g_LrjsXg.review_text: On a COLD and CLOUDY night, my family decided to take me to a dock on Fisherman's Wharf for a birthday "surprise."  If I didn't know any better, their "surprise" seemed more like a staged kidnapping. How frightening! With storm clouds looming over us and no one in sight, it seemed like one of those scenes out of a horror movie. You know, the one where a predator or some mystical figure pop out of nowhere to terrorize those poor, poor innocent souls.   As we waited on the dock, one of my sisters frantically looked for a phone to summon a shuttle boat to take us onto an "island." Incidentally, if you're trying to escape from a predator, don't waste your time looking for the phone because it's subtly hidden (so, it might take a little while of searching before you find your "life saver"). After waiting for 5-10 minutes, our little shuttle boat came to whisk us away, and guess who our captain was? That's right, the owner himself. He was extremely nice and incredibly funny. That was a pleasant surprise! But, at this point, I was still a bit apprehensive because I wasn't exactly sure where I was being taken to. For all I know, we could have been heading towards another Alcatraz.   Once we entered the restaurant, which is in a makeshift boat and is located below deck, I felt like we had been transported to another time period (perhaps to the 70s era). That being said, this adorable little place (and its nautical-themed décor) was super cozy, and the ambiance was great (albeit a little dimly lit for me)! They have different dining room themes that you can be seated in: Main Dining Salon (which is underwater), Tahiti Room, or Sea Lion Room.  Everyone was so nice here. The hostess greeted us with a nice, big smile and our waitress was more than accommodating. Our waitress was hilarious, making our dining experience there AMAZING! She also made great recommendations (glad I went with her suggestion), which was a plus. Not to mention, she came by often to check if everything was alright. One of the best customer services I've experienced.  If I had any doubts about this place, they were definitely gone by the time I took a bite out of my food. Their clam chowder was perfect for a cold day, and it was absolutely delicious. It was so creamy and rich, and the flavors were excellent. The organic Canadian Salmon was even more splendid. The creamy and tangy sauce that comes with the salmon was absolutely mouthwatering, and the salmon was cooked just right (it was so moist and tender). I wanted to order something for dessert, but I was so stuffed by the end of the meal, so I had to forgo that. (Although their menu is a bit on the pricier end and their portions aren't huge, their food is amazing and is worth the price!)  After finishing your meal, don't leave too soon. Before departing the "island," you should definitely go up to the lighthouse. I know that the last thing you want to do after finishing your meal is to make your way up a flight of stairs. But, believe me, you won't regret it. Once you've reached the top of this spiral staircase, you'll be rewarded with a breathtaking view of San Francisco. It's a perfect picture-taking moment (and you could even possibly share it on Instagram or FB...you know you want to).    If my family ever wants to kidnap me to this eerily place again, I'd be more than happy to volunteer myself. It's definitely a dining experience you should experience for yourself.     Tip: If you're coming here for dinner, make RESERVATIONS because this place gets pretty crowded (you can call them or book it online). Also, you might want to make reservations well in advance because they do get BOOKED UP really quickly.

bQAMexjyRZ7HKd3v2pHdig.review_text: This place is adorable and worth a trip.  You get on a little ferry for a really brief trip out there - it is in the bay but completely surrounded by docks and jettys - don't worry about rough water.  The little island has a lighthouse, a small outdoor seating area, and then you go downstairs to the restaurant.    It was chilly the night we ate there, but there was a warm and cozy fire going in the restaurant.  The staff all seem very pleasant and help with the festive atmosphere, welcoming you to the experience.  With all of the ambience, we figured it was not going to be about the food - so were very pleasantly surprised with our dinners - they were delicious, fresh fish and nice desserts.  We both had the special sole, and crème brulee for dessert.    Don't miss a trip to the ladies' room - it is entered through the cabin of the man who once lived here - full of antiques and lovely -even the male guests peeked in to enjoy the ambience of this place.  We really enjoyed it.  As others have said, the little dock is not immediately apparent, but not too hard to find from the pier and worth looking for.  We totally enjoyed this place.

nli-63fBmK8gnpZbrFf44A.review_text: The most amazing venue for private parties in the city.  Great spot for a date or just to sit at the comfy bar and have a cocktail.  Rooms surrounded buy glass, fire pit inside, out of town guests would be blown away...locals feel like they are in a different world.  AND its so close.

nyXNNLKjSWtDQka5PrFoew.review_text: A friend of mine mentioned this restaurant on an Island and I was instantly intrigued. When my bf's birthday rolled around I instantly made a reservation.   First and foremost, this is a pretty touristy place. It's smack in the middle of Fisherman's Wharf. Granted, they validate parking for 2 hours at the Pier 39 parking garage so it wasn't too bad. But the hoards of people made the experience getting there a little painful.   After parking, we saw the restaurant and I was disappointed to see that it was literally a few feet away from the dock. Uh....why can't you just build a bridge so you can get rid of the boat ride? Gimmick. Again, I was disappointed by how beat up the boat was, not fancy or romantic at all. And the ride was literally 3 minutes long, so there were no views to enjoy whatsoever. A waste of time in my opinion.   We ended up sitting in one of the tiki rooms, which had a nice view of the water and the sealions. But occasionally when the wind blew we could feel it swaying. People prone to seasickness beware. The food actually ended up being delicious. It was nothing innovative; just solid hearty dishes. Service was fantastic and we ended up learning alot about the history of Forbe's Island. We also walked up the lighthouse and explored the main dining area that's actually submerged underwater.   Overall, the price for the food alone was a little high. But you are paying for the touristy gimmicky experience and history, which I surprisingly enjoyed alot. Pretty sure I will not come back unless I'm with someone from out of town, but it's something worth checking out once if you live in the Bay Area.

CvXzuQWjexjd0XzW5HNwTw.user_location: North Beach/Telegraph Hill, San Francisco, CA
CvXzuQWjexjd0XzW5HNwTw.review_text: I don't see why people give this place 4 stars and their only complaint was the swaying. It's a floating island, it's moored to the dock.... Anyways food was amazing, atmosphere was romantic, we even saw fish in the portholes! It's was a wonderful experience. Kc our waiter was wonderful, all the wait staff did a fantastic job and the manager was very helpful and made sure to talk to everyone! Great experience, well worth the money.

4ufbBE3kh1oWCsvJzVUSiA.review_text: Ok first it's not an island. It's a floating barge-really! Went as a couple and was greeted by captain/owner who didn't talk to us on ride to "island". Food was overcooked-had to flake off the top of my salmon from crispy underside. husband ribs were also lightly burnt. Waitress showed up only for order and didn't check in with us the rest of the time. $12 for half shot of amaretto. The finish was waiting 30 min outside in the windy cold for owner to take us back across. Had to go to bar where owner was chatting it up and advise that we wanted to go. Waited another 15 min for him to drag himself topside. No tour of "island from anyone". Better views and better food to be had elsewhere!!!!  p.s. forbes your busboy -friendly and efficient-was the only saving grace to your place.

5Ftb40mmwptuN-QGBfGXbA.review_text: Forbes Island is an experience. My boyfriend surprised me by bringing me hear to celebrate Valentines day earlier.   We took the first boat/trip to Forbes Island at 5pm among a couple of other couples. Expecting to go far (somewhere met Alcatraz), I was surprised when we ended basically the equivalent of 4 blocks out to the bay.  Forbes Island is a neat concept - an "island" (basically a boat) off of the bay. The main dining room is below so if there were windows to look out you could potentially see sea life. However the main dining room is dimly lit.  Thinking this was an island, we didn't take motion sickness pills and the boat-"island" was some what rafty, I was not TOTALLY at peace.  The food is alright. I think it is a bit overpriced for the quality of food. Boyfriend and I both orders flat iron steak and it was good. We also split a soup de Jour which happened to be New England Chowder - it was good. And then ordered a side shiitake mushroom and broccoli side - which came out as a cube - which was interesting.   Overall: I'm glad I came. The company was awesome but wouldn't come back. If you're looking for something new and different, this is one to try but if you're looking for a high end dining/food experience, I recommend looming elsewhere
